DOC.HEAD: Israel Names New Ambassador To The United States
DOC.TEXT: The new government Sunday approved the nomination of Zalman Shoval as its ambassador to the United States, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said. Shoval, 60, a legislator from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, will resign from the parliament, or Knesset, before assuming his post, the spokesman said. The replacement will take effect at the end of September after the U.S. administration agrees to the nomination in accordance with diplomatic protocol, he said. Shoval himself, speaking on Israel army radio, expressed hope he would encounter a more positive atmosphere in Washington than did his predecessor, Moshe Arad. The U.S. administration has been increasingly critical of the Jewish state over its failed peace efforts with the Palestinians. They have been waging a 32-month rebellion against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Shoval said the U.S. administration, due to the Persian Gulf crisis, now appears to realize that ``the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is not the main reason for conflict in the Middle East and that Israel is in the end the only stable ally the United States has in the Middle East.'' The Polish-born Shoval is an veteran Israeli politician who is also experienced in diplomacy. In 1955-1957, he worked at the Foreign Ministry, where he rose from a cadet to the post of deputy head of the North American desk.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Dampens Festivities At End Of Motorcycle Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to move up reference to deaths. pick up 16th graf pvs, `Sturgis residents...
DOC.TEXT: Long strings of motorcycles roared out of western South Dakota on Sunday as the weeklong 50th Black Hills Motor Classic came to a violence-marred end. The event drew an estimated 300,000 bikers to the area. Its mostly peaceful, festive mood was dampened by a Saturday night shooting and stabbing brawl involving the Outlaws and Sons of Silence motorcycle gangs. Three men were injured. By Sunday, the event had claimed 11 lives. Nine people died in traffic accidents, one person was killed by carbon-monoxide poisoning in a tent, and police shot and killed a knife-wielding Australian man who charged the officers. Law officers issued 1,060 traffic tickets and 2,143 warnings, and made 202 drunken driving and 73 drug arrests. Officials reported 133 traffic accidents, 78 involving injuries. The fight occurred Saturday night at Gunner's Lounge and Casino on Main Street, usually a hangout for Hells Angels during the event, officials said. Two Sons of Silence members were hospitalized in stable but serious condition Sunday with stab wounds, said Meade County Sheriff Floyd Cleland. A member of the Outlaws was treated for gunshot wounds and released. The stabbing victims will be charged with aggravated assault, and the gunshot victim may also be charged, Cleland said. ``It sure puts a damper on people having a good time,'' said Matt Waller of Gillette, Wyo., who operated a food stand near the Main Street bar where the fight occurred. By Sunday morning, the scene on Main Street appeared to return to normal. Bikers again rode and walked the route around a huge cluster of motorcycles parked down the center and along the length of the street. The violence didn't take anyone by surprise. ``As I've said before, the potential is there,'' Cleland said. ``These people all drink booze, take drugs and carry knives and guns.'' ``With this amount of people, you know there's going to be things happen. There's going to be accidents. There's going to be fights,'' said Bill Kienast, who works at a truck-building company in Oshkosk, Wis. Marcy Myhre, executive director of the Sturgis Area Chamber of Commerce's Black Hills Motor Classic Board, noted that last year's rally drew only 60,000 people. The week went well, except for a few incidents of violence, she said. ``We put a lot of effort into it, and it's too bad things like that have to happen.'' Some Sturgis residents have tried to stop the rally, but most seem to accept and even enjoy the crowds that invade the town of 7,000 one week each year. According to conservative estimates, the bikers and other visitors spent at least $34 million in the town and surrounding Black Hills. ``A lot of them feel it was a little too much, but a lot of them realize this is a once-in-a-lifetime crowd, too,'' Myhre said. Sturgis residents Ken and Barb Grosch were on Main Street Saturday night _ before the riot _ recorded images of people and motorcycles with a video camera. ``It's nice to see a small, boring town come alive,'' said Mrs. Grosch. ``I think it's great, but after a week or so I'm ready to see them go home.'' Main Street was the center of activity, with thousands of motorcycles parked in the middle of the street and at the curb, and bikers sporting leather and tattoos as they gathered around their ``hogs.'' Merlin Rosen, a veterinary student from Fort Collins, Colo., posed with two boa constrictors wrapped around her neck and arms. ``Everybody has to stop and look, and there's always the attraction of being seen,'' she said. Biker gangs weren't the only ones who showed up for the week of races and other events. There are many motorcycle enthusiasts among the well-heeled; the late Malcolm Forbes attended last year's rally.

Money Shortages Choking Reform in Big City Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For years, Philadelphia schools have offered students a chance to study Latin as early as fourth grade. But this fall, fewer kids will learn their ``amo, amas, amat's'': a tight budget has forced the layoff of six out of 26 itinerant Latin teachers. ``An awful lot of them won't even finish high school, and the only language they are exposed to is street language. This is the one opportunity they have to get a little something beyond that,''said one laid-off Latin teacher, H. Michael Dunn. Many such cuts, affecting both innovative programs and day-to-day operations, await big-city districts across the country this fall. A check by The Associated Press found that districts from Philadelphia, Boston and New York to Dade County, Fla., and Los Angeles face the worst fiscal problems since the mid-'70s. ``It's going to be tough to innovate when you're trying to survive,'' said James Fleming, associate superintendent of Dade County schools, a district that gained national notice for school reforms but now faces a $108 million deficit that will likely lead to more crowded classes. With a possible recession looming and worsening state finances putting a squeeze on school budgets, big-city school officials everywhere are bracing for teacher hiring freezes, layoffs, and larger classes. ``It's a very bleak fall,'' said Jewell Gould, research director of the American Federation of Teachers. He and others believe next spring could bring even worse news when districts customarily send out layoff notices. One leading reformer called this fall's cutbacks fresh evidence that political leaders give more lip service than resources to school improvement. ``If snow is piling up in city streets, you get a greater sense of emergency than if half the kids drop out of school year after year,'' said Ernest L. Boyer, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. ``On the one hand, we say education is at the center of what we hope for and dream about, and we almost get maudlin about it. But then if something happens, it gets put off as `kid stuff,''' he said. ``This is easily the worst fiscal crisis I have seen in the last 20 years,'' said Fleming of Dade County. State funding fell $44 million less than expected, said Dade County school spokesman Andy Gollan. It's already meant elimination of a merit schools program where schools devised innovative programs to help students achieve educational goals. Philadelphia, anticipating deficits of $68 million for fiscal year 1991-92, $170 million in 1993, and $275 million in 1994, has put on hold reforms including full-day kindergartens, lengthening the school day and year, and more classroom computers. ``It's come to a period where we have to make hard choices, which are not necessarily popular choices,'' said Leontine D. Scott, associate superintendent. In Boston, a $397 million budget approved last week is $6.4 million lower than last year's. Cuts include 100 fewer non-tenured teachers, fewer school police, reduced extracurricular and after-school programs, less funding for a city-financed parent organization, and reductions in a private industry council that provides jobs for high-school students. The city's schoolchildren are ``treated like second-class citizens because they don't have the political clout that other communities have,'' said Boston School Committee member Peggy Davis Mullen. In Los Angeles, a $220 million budget gap earlier this year forced extensive administrative cuts. The crisis worsened last week when Gov. George Deukmejian announced he was withholding $465 million in school funds statewide, compelling the district to cut $77 million more from the 1990-91 budget. School officials haven't decided yet how to parcel out the cuts. But a number of reform ideas have already been shelved or reduced. A Bilingual Master Plan designed to help non-English speaking students in all major subject areas has been only partially funded. The district is also postponing expansion of its school-based management program in which more than 60 schools participate. ``Devastating would not be too strong a word,'' said school board member Rita Walters. ``It just socks it to us.'' New York City's school board must come up with $26.8 million in instructional cuts this fall after having already eliminated some 350 jobs at the central board. ``How that will be done is the unanswered question,'' said Susan Amlung, a spokeswoman for the United Federation of Teachers. The district is likely to cut school aides and paraprofessionals, measures that the union fears will put more students in already-overcrowded classes. School officials insist that won't happen. Kindergarten classes currently average 24.8 pupils, and high-school classes of 40 or more are not uncommon. Seattle's $243.6 million school budget has meant eliminating 165 teaching, administrative and other positions, mainly through attrition. ``It's been a difficult time,'' said Seattle schools budget manager George Steinhofer. ``We've taken a number of reductions in central administration and this year we took reductions in special education and bilingual programs. The only place left to look is in basic educational programs.'' New Orleans is closing two of its three centers for problem students, and 60 school employees were laid off to balance the $358 million budget, said superintendent Everett Williams. ``That's been the story of our life in this school district for the past four or five years. I have had no budget that's been an even budget, where I have been able to start off the year with no cuts at all,'' he said. In Houston, Superintendent Joan Raymond is pushing for a record 18 percent tax rate hike to fund a $797.9 million budget. The proposed budget would provide a 10 percent pay raise for teachers, 31 new principals and deans, a dropout prevention program, beefed up security, a principal performance incentive program and funding of a massive construction program. But some taxpayers are resisting: ``By no extent of the imagination is the public going along with this, '' said John Pellicciotti, a board member of the Taxpayers Coalition of Greater Houston. Not all cities are in such dire straits. In Atlanta, public schools comptroller Lawrence Thompson said the district has not had cuts. Next year's budget is $331.3 million, compared with $319.3 million this past school year. ``We've been pretty fortunate,'' Thompson said. Newark, with a $421 million school budget, has an $8.5 million shortfall but has largely avoided layoffs. Some assistant principals and other administrators may be demoted to save money, said spokesman Kirk Smith. Next year, the district will get as much as $50 million in additional funds as part of a state plan to boost the quality of New Jersey city schools. But another state plan to shift teacher pension costs entirely to local districts could cancel out those gains, Smith said. In Detroit, an $889 million budget for the 1990-91 school year includes such reform initiatives as expanded preschools and special schools meant to help troubled ninth-graders avoid disciplinary problems. A 5-mill property tax increase and a bond issue approved by voters last September wiped out the district's $160 million deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Look at U.S. Editorial Pages' Views of Desert Showdown
With Iraq-Kuwait Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from editorials on the Middle East crisis in Sunday editions of U.S. newspapers:
DOC.HEAD: Dallas Times Herald
DOC.TEXT: The Mideast crisis triggered by the decision of militaristic Iraq to seize one oil-producing nation and threaten the conquest of others has, predictably, destabilized the world's energy network. ... What is surprising _ and inexcusable _ is that America enters this state of confusion without an energy policy any more comprehensive than the hapless policies of 1973. The Iraqi threat to one of the world's major oil-producing regions should force the development of an energy policy designed to secure the nation's energy needs. ... A national energy policy is long overdue.
DOC.HEAD: The News Tribune, Tacoma, Wash.
DOC.TEXT: Faster than anyone had bargained for, America is learning what it will take to defend its national interests in the post-Cold War era. Neither hawks nor doves of the old school are enjoying the lesson. ... One lesson of Kuwait is that the United States must maintain enough military strength to protect its commerce and citizens from pirates like Hussein. This is a depressing prospect for doves who have been gleefully preparing to cut America's defense budget. Middle East events haven't been kind to Cold War hawks, either. ... European armies, MIRVed missiles and $800 million bombers aren't much use against the likes of Hussein. The crises America is likely to face in the foreseeable future will demand strong airborne and Marine forces, light armor, tactical air and naval power, much of it able to move on a day's notice to any trouble spot in the world.
DOC.HEAD: The Journal-Constitution, Atlanta
DOC.TEXT: Saddam wants to be seen as a military strongman who gets what he needs through brute strength. He sees hostage-takingy, correctly, as the desperate resort of the powerless and not worthy of the self-proclaimed leader of the Arab world. Not yet that is. If they are not actual hostages, the foreign nationals held by Iraq represent insurance for Saddam. They are his rainy-day fund, so to speak. If and when his situation deteriorates, which it will, they will become far more valuable. They will become, in truth, hostages. It is the rule of the Middle East bazaar: Any Americans held hostage by Iraq become worth what we are willing to pay. The more preoccupied we become with getting them back, the more unlikely they will be released at a price we are capable of paying.
DOC.HEAD: Star Tribune, Minneapolis
DOC.TEXT: ...By snatching Kuwait, Hussein injected uncertainty into the worldwide oil system. Uncertainty affects prices because oil selling today has to be priced at what it will cost tomorrow to replace it. Uncertainty affects supplies because consumers from the motorist to the refiner to the gas-pump jockey lay in extra in case shortages develop, thereby creating supply disruptions. ... Whether in the Persian Gulf or at home, bad oil news will be telegraphed to Americans via their local gas pump. They should get mad: at themselves if they continue to let their dependence on imported oil make them vulnerable to madmen.
DOC.HEAD: The Sunday Journal, Providence, R.I.
DOC.TEXT: ... It should be said that the Arab League's decision (to send Arab troops to defend Saudi Arabia) is one of the more hopeful signs for the future of world peace since World War II. For it therapeutically destroys the myth of Arab unity _ a fantasy based on the preposterous but powerful assumption that the various Arab countries comprise one ``Arab nation.'' ... (Saddam) has forced fellow Arabs to choose between civilized international behavior and a bloody-minded Arab dictator. It also represents a great personal victory for President Bush and for U.S. efforts to create a global force to thwart Iraqi aggression. The President has spent much time and energy trying to ensure that the world community, and not just the West, condemns and confronts Baghdad.
DOC.HEAD: The Sunday Sun, Baltimore
DOC.TEXT: There's an immediate lesson to be drawn from the confrontation in the Persian Gulf. ... The danger of this country's crushing dependence on imported oil. In part that's a legacy of the Reagan years but it is also a failure of industry and consumers to recognize the advantages of alternate energy sources. There aren't any quick-fix solutions. The fastest and cheapest way to respond to the cutback in oil imports would be a national conservation program. The president, in concert with the nation's governors and mayors, ought to act immediately to curb profligate use of petroleum. We can no longer remain complacent about importing 50 percent of our petroleum. This imbalance must be ended. Our future economic well-being is at stake.
DOC.HEAD: The Columbus (Ohio) Dispatch
DOC.TEXT: Although U.S. military experts grow more sanguine as each hour passes, the wild card in this is the unpredictability of the volatile Saddam, a man who has used poison gas against the Kurds in his own country and against teen-age Iranian soldiers. His volatility makes military planning against him more difficult. ... Saddam can rant all he wants, but he is up against formidable odds. His whole economy is based on the Iraqis' ability to sell their oil, so as long as the blockade is successful, it amounts to an economic choke-hold. The events played out in the sands of the Middle East will surely have repercussions on the U.S. domestic front, in terms of both energy and defense policies.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: defense policies.
The Washington Post
DOC.TEXT: It is heartening to see Egypt exercising leadership in the strategy to force Iraq out of Kuwait. For the United States and Europe, the primary interest in political stability there is the flow of oil. Iraq's neighbors have much more at stake. Iraq has made it clear that its intentions go beyond this month's conquest. It proposes to make itself dominant among the Arabs. Saddam Hussein has been claiming, in recent days, to speak for all the Arab world in a great test of will and of strength with the Americans. But most of the Arab world denounced him on Friday in the Arab League's meeting, and now Egyptian forces as well as Americans face him at the Saudi border.
DOC.HEAD: The Detroit News
DOC.TEXT: No one in Washington, it seems, wants to use the ``H'' word _ hostages _ to describe the several thousand Americans who were caught in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the latter's blitzkrieg conquest of the former two weeks ago. With every day that passes without their being allowed to leave, however, it becomes harder to avoid the conclusion that they are being held against their will. (President Bush) should set a deadline for the unconditional release of the Americans. Failure to comply will result in attacks on Iraqi oil fields and other targets. Harm to any Americans would be considered an act of all-out war.
DOC.HEAD: The Philadelphia Inquirer
DOC.TEXT: An Arab force on the Saudi border will signal that an attack will embroil him (Hussein) in an inter-Arab war. It is hoped that this would also undercut his attempt to portray himself as the hero who would save Arab oil fields and Muslim holy places from unclean Western hands. ... The real test of global cooperation against Iraq will be if that blockade holds. It could take months for sanctions to move Baghdad, and Saddam Hussein will undoubtedly counterattack. He may use hostages or terrorism, or undermine Arab leaders who stand up to him. It will take patience, and test White House leadership, to keep a global blockade going. But the best inspiration to stick together may come from listening to the words of Saddam Hussein.
DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Times
DOC.TEXT: The crisis provoked by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has escalated into the first major confrontation of the post-Cold War era and new realities, both hopeful and sobering, are emerging. Foremost among the latter is the realization that a world liberated from the threat of nuclear annihilation will not be free of mortal danger. As the case of Saddam Hussein makes all too clear, there remain good old-fashioned nationalist dictators every bit as aggressive and threatening as Stalinist ideologues. ... But ... much that has transpired so far should be a source of hope. The willingness of the vast majority of the world's nations to directly and collectively engage Hussein's challenge is, as foreign policy analyst Stanley Hoffman put it, ``quite remarkable.'' In fact, if the anti-Hussein coalition holds together, this crisis could, as former diplomat Richard N. Gardner has said, ``constitute a landmark event in the history of this century.''

DOC.HEAD: I Don't Care Who You Call Me, but Get My Title Right
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Every Malay who is anybody has a title, from the duli yang maha mulia seri paduka baginda yang di-pertuan agong _ that's the king _ to each haji and hajah who makes the Moslem pilgrimage to Mecca. Tun, tan seri and datuk are among the many hereditary or conferred titles borne by leading citizens. Proper ways of addressing a Malay are diverse and complicated. Family names are relatively unimportant as long as the title is used correctly. Improper usage may cause offense. Some titles are gained at birth, others given as rewards for service to government or nation. To the ordinary encik (mister), titles and forms of address can be confusing. The king's title means, approximately, ``his most glorious majesty who is raised most high.'' In English, ``your majesty'' is usually enough. The queen, or seri baginda raja permaisuri agong, also is ``your majesty.'' Malaysia is unique in having a monarchy that rotates among royal families. Nine of the 13 states have royal families, whose leaders take turns being king of the entire nation for five years. Passing the throne around solved a sticky protocol problem when Malaysia shed colonial ties with Britain in 1957. None of the nine state rulers would have been accepted by the other eight as permanent king and Tunku Abdul Rahman, who was prime minister, divised the method of sharing glory. Children of the state rulers usually are called tunku or tengku, loosely equivalent to prince or princess. Tunku Rahman, for example, is of royal descent. Niks and megats are those with royal blood on the mother's side. Syeds and their female counterparts, sharifahs, claim to be directly descended from the prophet Mohammed, from royal families of the Malay archipelago, or both. A man honored for distinguished service to the nation becomes a tun and his wife a toh puan. The title is Malaysia's highest order of chivalry, limited to 25 living men. When Prime Minister Dato Seri Dr. Mahathir Mohamad retires, officials say, he probably will become Tun Mahathir. He is a medical doctor and was made a dato seri years ago for his contributions to public life. The non-hereditary title tan seri is given to the recipient of either of Malaysia's two second-highest orders of chivalry for non-royals. Datuks, and the variants datuk seri and dato, are numerous and their wives are datins. The title is non-hereditary and its basic meaning is grandfather. In higher social circles, practically everybody is a datuk, whether Malay, Chinese or Indian. A common compliment is to call a man dato before he has been so designated. Few object, except the very modest. The highlight of the king's official birthday, celebrated on the first Wednesday of June, is the conferment of hundreds of awards and titles. Hundreds more are issued each year by the 13 states, with datuk in the majority. Tuan means sir in Malay, and is used informally to address an elderly person or someone of prominence or wealth. Tuan yang terutama, the Malay translation of excellency, is applied to heads of diplomatic missions and the governors of the four states without royal families. Puan, or madame, often is used to refer to married women. A single women is called cik. Haji and hajah are the titles for men and women who have made a pilgrimage, or haj, to Mecca and performed certain acts required on a pilgrimage. In Malay usage, bin means ``son of'' and binte means ``daughter of.'' The part of the name before it is the given name, and the part after is the name of the person's father. Names can be as confusing as titles. The prime minister is Mahathir Mohamad, the information minister is Mohamed Rahmat and thousands of others spell the name Mohamat, Muhamat, Muhhammad and even Mohd. In 1988, the goverment decreed the official version of the prophet's name to be Muhammad. Those already born and named with other spellings were excused from compliance.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Child Wins Back Matisse Painting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT spelling of Matisse in lead and restore first reference to artist in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The great-granddaughter of photographer Edward Steichen has won back a Matisse painting valued at $800,000 after a legal battle with the Museum of Modern Art, according to a published report. But 6-year-old Ariana Rodina Calderone Stahmer probably will never see the painting in her home because it will be sold to cover legal bills her family has to pay, The New York Times reported in Sunday editions. The Times said the museum settled out of court on Friday but terms of the arrangement in federal court in Bridgeport, Conn., were not made public. The child's family spent more than $100,000 in legal fees in the dispute, the newspaper reported. Henri Matisse presented Edward Steichen with the painting, ``Vue de Collioure a l'Eglise,'' in 1908 to thank him for helping arrange the first American exhibition of his works and to commemorate the birth of Steichen's daughter, Kate. Steichen gave Kate Steichen the painting on her 53rd birthday, and she in turn loaned it to the museum in 1973, the year her father died. She died in 1988 and the museum and the family have argued over the painting ever since. The museum Miss Steichen donated the painting to the museum. The family said Miss Steichen bequeathed the painting to her grandniece, Ariana, who lives in Pennington, N.J. ``It's a little bit late,'' said the girl's father, Joel Stahmer. ``They felt they could wait us out in terms of money. They were as uncharitable as a charitable organization can be.'' Richard E. Oldenburg, director of the museum, issued a statement that said in part: ``Given its long relationship with Edward Steichen, the museum does not wish to be in conflict with the his family.'' Steichen was in charge of the museum's photography department from 1947 to 1962 and put together a number of exhibitions, including the widely viewed ``The Family of Man.'' Ariana's mother, Francesca Calderone-Steichen, told the Times she was selling the painting, which she had hoped to hang in her daughter's bedroom. ``I feel very sad,'' she said. ``She adored my aunt and this would have been a way to keep that bond. Now the painting is never going to be in the house. The only way she'll see it is in a book.'' In April, when the lawsuit was filed, lawyers for the estate contended the museum was waging a war of attrition against a modest estate, a stategy they say would eventually backfire. ``Who else is going to lend works to the Museum of Modern Art if they're afraid they'll treat loans as gifts?'' asked attorney L. Douglas Shrader, who filed the lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Key Medellin Cartel Figure Killed In Gunfight With Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Gaviria associate detained, background; No Pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police shot and killed a key member of the violent Medellin cocaine cartel Saturday in a gunbattle in one of Medellin's exclusive neighborhoods, police said. Gustavo de Jesus Gaviria, the cousin of the cartel's leader, Pablo Escobar, was killed at 4:00 p.m. A local hospital did not identify his body until four hours later. Gaviria, who authorities said was the third most important member of the drug cartel, exchanged gunfire with police before being killed, according to a police statement. The statement gave no details about how police located Gaviria in the luxury apartment, which was equipped with bullet-resistant windows. The apartment was located in southern Medellin's Alaneda neighborhood. A police spokesman said in Medellin that one of Gaviria's associates, Alexandra Tapias, was detained in the operation, carried out by a special anti-narcotics police unit. Gaviria is the third cartel leader killed in gunbattles with police during the past eight months. He is the main partner of Escobar, the Medellin cartel leader blamed for a terrorist campaign of bombs and other attacks that have killed hundreds of people over the past year. Police say Gaviria acted as his first cousin's front man in several business transactions and that several of Escobar's properties are registered in Gaviria's name. Gaviria was wanted for extradition to the United States on drug trafficking charges. The Medellin cartel last month called a truce in a year-long terrorist campaign, saying it was yielding to Colombian's desire for peace. The cartel said in a communique that the government should respond to the peace overture by ending its policy of extraditing drug traffickers to the United States. Colombian President Cesar Gaviria said after taking office last week that both extraditions and the crackdown on traffickers would continue. All Medellin police officers were ordered to their posts late Saturday because of fears the cartel may call off the truce following Gaviria's death. Last December, police shot and killed Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha on Colombia's northern coast. Along with Escobar, Rodriguez Gacha was considered one of the cartel's most violent leaders. Police shot and killed another major cartel figure, John Jairo Arias, earlier this year in Medellin. Arias was said to have coordinated the cartel's terrorist campaign. The cartel began the campaign last August after the government announced its antidrug crackdown in response to the assassination of a presidential candidate. The government has seized hundreds of properties of suspected traffickers and ordered the extradition of Colombians wanted on drug charges in the United States. Since August, the government has extradited 22 drug trafficking suspects.

DOC.HEAD: Small-Town Police Undaunted By 300,000-Biker Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Another shooting...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with more shooting details. Restores dropped word `been' in final sentence of 11th graf. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `Bush said...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XSTG2
DOC.TEXT: All week long the authorities of this town of 7,000 have struggled to contain an ocean of roaring motorcycles and tattooed bikers wrapped in enough leather to outfit the women of Chicago with purses. On Friday, when the crowd had swelled to around 300,000, Police Chief Jim Bush faced one of his most serious challenges _ a showdown on Main Street between two motorcycle gangs. Luckily, the conflict broke off before knives were drawn. And Bush said the police involvement in cooling tempers was, shall we say, discreet. ``We didn't break anything up. We just kind of stood back,'' he said. The 50th Black Hills Motor Classic, with bikers from every state and dozens of countries, rattled toward its official close Sunday, and police in this Black Hills town near the Wyoming border were breathing many sighs of relief. Thursday night, a lead biker of the Outlaws motorcycle gang smiled at a police officer, cocked his finger like a pistol and gave him a little ``pow!'' It was a small gesture, more playful than menacing, but it signified some of the problems that Sturgis has had to cope with in putting on the world's largest motorcycle gathering. Sturgis, which normally has 10 officers, in 10 days has provided a year's worth of mayhem. Since Aug. 1, hundreds of law enforcement agents have issued 976 traffic tickets, given out 1,918 warnings, arrested 180 people for drunken driving and 61 others on drug charges. They also have handled 116 reported accidents, 65 involving injuries. The rally has been the scene of nine traffic-related deaths. Police shot to death an Australian man, and a North Dakota woman died of carbon monoxide poisoning. There have been a few non-fatal stabbings. Law officers interviewed members of the Outlaws and Hells' Angels Saturday night after one person was wounded in a shooting at a downtown bar and two people were stabbed after what witnesses described as a dispute between two motorcycle groups, Meade County State's Attorney Mike Jackley said.. The wounded were alive after the shooting at Gunner's Lounge and Casino and the stabbings near the Sooper Dooper grocery, but their conditions at a nearby hospital were not immediately available, he said. Bush said he was not surprised by the number of fatalities. ``I thought there would probably be more, I really did, with this many people,'' he said. The annual biker festival draws gangs such as the Hells' Angels, The Bandidos, and the Sons of Silence, as well as clubs sponsored by Christian groups and Alcoholics Anonymous. The late Malcolm Forbes was at last year's fest. A coroner's jury Friday ruled that three officers acted in the ``scope of their duty'' when they shot Trevor John Hansen, of Liverpool, Australia. Hansen allegedly lunged at them with a knife Tuesday. Police were responding to a report he had driven his 2-foot-long knife through the door of a house, broke in and held the knife under the nose of a resident. ``Aside from (the shooting), we have not seen anything really outside of what we ordinarily have seen,'' said state Attorney General Roger Tellinghuisen. ``Except it's on a larger scale. And that's to be expected. There are three times as many people here,'' Tellinghuisen said.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Case of Diphtheria Worries Health Officials
DOC.TEXT: A rare case of diphtheria, diagnosed in an 18-year-old woman, prompted a warning this weekend by worried health officials. Most children are immunized against the potentially lethal disease when they begin school, but they can outgrow the immunity, said Dr. Linda A. Fisher, chief medical examiner of St. Louis County. She issued a warning Saturday, asking adults not to overlook the symptoms of diphtheria, which include sore throat, fever, cough and difficulty swallowing. Diphtheria features the development of a greenish-gray membrane in the throat. The membrane can block the airway, causing respiratory failure. The woman was listed in serious condition Saturday at St. John's Mercy Medical Center in Creve Coeur, Fisher said. She was diagnosed with diphtheria on Friday after showing symptoms for about a week. Dr. Farrin Manian, an infectious disease specialist who is treating the woman, said state records indicate this may be the first Missouri diphtheria case in 15 years. He said medical literature showed fewer than five cases in the United States in the last 10 years.
