DOC.TEXT: Iraq is now enjoying ``an era of pride and happiness,'' Saddam said. But the Iraqi president warned that unless the mujahedat, or female holy warriors, implement his appeal, ``The future will bring an era of Americanism and Zionism and the Arab nation will lose its only chance to establish an infrastructure for the march toward liberation and an end to the oppression, hunger and slavery.'' ``Victory depends on success of this for us and our generations,'' Saddam said. `Today, you have additional responsibilities to those you had shouldered before. You are called to take on a special role in all the social and domestic affairs.'' Saddam said women should now also take it upon themselves to organize Iraq's economic life. ``It is when the economic life is organized in accordance with the overall plan we seek, that we can consider the battle over in favor of Iraq and the the invaders deceived, fleeing one after the other,'' Saddam said. ``It is then that we will possess all the potentials to take on all the amassed forces of evil and those who might be massed in the next two months,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Turkish Premier Asks Lawmakers for Power to Declare War
DOC.TEXT: The premier said on Sunday he will ask Parliament for the power to declare a state of war and send armed forces into combat in the event of an escalation of the Persian Gulf crisis. Premier Yildirim Akbulut made the announcement before the start of an extraordinary session of Parliament to discuss the crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and massing of troops on Saudi Arabia's border. A multinational force led by the United States is being sent to Saudi Arabia to protect that nation against a possible Iraqi invasion, and some news reports have said that Iraq also is building up troops on Turkey's border. ``This is not an authorization we are going to use now,'' Akbulut said, describing it as a precautionary measure. He told deputies of his governing Motherland Party that ``we have no intention of going to war. But we cannot remain indiffeent when there is a state of war next door to us.'' ``There is no intention of any agression on our part, this is a purely defensive measure,'' he said. President Turgut Ozal told reporters on Saturday that the government could ask for war powers authorization ``just in case, to be prepared for any eventuality.'' This would make it easier to take fast action in case of a surprise attack, he said. Under the Turkish Constitution, approval from Parliament is required to send Turkish troops abroad in a war or to allow foreign combat troops to be stationed in the country. Sunday's session was sought by opposition parties, which have been warning the government to refrain from ``a foreign adventure'' that could land Turkey in a war in the region. Parliament had been on a recess. Complying with U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq, Turkey on Tuesday effectively closed down two Iraqi pipelines through the country and banned all trade except emergency food and medical supplies. The Turkish military also has been taking measures described by the nation's leaders as defensive precautions against a possible Iraqi attack. Diplomatic and military analysts say such an attack unlikely given the size of Turkey's 800,000-strong army, its population of 55 million against Iraq's 17 million, its self-sufficiency in food and its developed industrial base. Also, NATO has assured Turkey it will protect its only Moslem member in the event of Iraqi aggression.

DOC.HEAD: Army Says 116 Moslems Killed In Tamil Assault
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Tamil guerrillas denying they carried out the attacks on Moslems. Pickup 12th, `On Aug...'
DOC.TEXT: Tamil guerrillas killed at least 116 people in an assault on five Moslem villages in Sri Lanka's escalating ethnic war, military officials said Sunday. A Tamil politician said the attacks were in retaliation for the killing of 33 Tamil civilians by Moslems using government-supplied weapons. The Tamil guerrillas claimed the killings were carried out by pro-government Tamil groups in an attempt to provoke sectarian clashes between Tamils and Moslems. About 50 gunmen threw hand grenades into houses and raked the Moslem villages with machine-gun fire late Saturday, the officials said on condition of anonymity. They said 116 bodies were counted and about 40 people were critically wounded. The attacks were on five villages west of Eravur, 125 miles east of Colombo, the officials said. Mohammed Saly, of the Moslem Refugee Relief Organization, said the assailants ``first hacked to death Moslem priests in a mosque to prevent them from using the loudspeakers to warn of the attack.'' They then attacked people in the five villages and shooting lasted three hours, Saly said. Villagers fled into the jungle to escape, he said. Army troops reached the region on Sunday morning from their camp at Chenkaladi about three miles away. It was not immediately clear why it took troops so long to reach the region. The largest of the villages attacked was called Saddam Hussein, after the Iraqi leader who sent building assistance several years ago, Saly said. The Tamil politician, Mahalingam Sivajilingam, said the killings Saturday were related to fatal attacks on Tamils earlier in the day. ``Armed Moslems raided a Tamil refugee camp on Saturday and abducted and killed 25 Tamil civilians, including seven women,'' said Sivajilingam. Another eight Tamil patients were killed in a hospital, he said. ``This led to the Tamil Tigers attacking the villages ... and killing innocent Moslems,'' he said. ``The two communities are on an annihilation spree. Nobody knows how many more will die before it all ends,'' said Savajilingam, a leader of the Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization, a former guerrilla group which gave up arms for politics. Lawrence Thilakar, a Tiger leader, said in a telephone call to the Colombo office of The Associated Press that the attacks on Moslems were carried out by pro-government Tamil groups to cause sectarian clashes. ``Why should we attack Moslems?'' he asked. ``We need the fullest cooperation of the Moslem people, who are also supressed at the hands of the government. This dangerous game being played by the government will not last long. Very soon, the truth will come out.'' Thilakar spoke from London, where the Tigers maintain a propaganda office. On Aug. 3 Tamil rebels raided another eastern village and gunned down 140 Moslems inside two Mosques, the military said. The Tamil Tigers later denied responsibility, but the incident set off vengeance killings on both sides. Tamil insurgents seeking independence from the Sinhalese-dominated government in Colombo broke a 13-month cease-fire on June 11. Though Moslems are not directly involved in the conflict, Tamils suspect them of acting as informers for the military. Before Saturday's incidents, 193 Moslems and about 60 Tamil civilians had died in the latest round of fighting, according to the military. Nearly 60 Sinhalese civilians have also died in attacks attributed to the Tigers. Since the fighting resumed, government troops have consolidated their hold on east coast villages, forcing the Tigers into the jungle. The Tigers remain in control of the northern Jaffna Peninsula.

DOC.HEAD: British Citizen Reportedly Shot Near Saudi Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Foreign Office saying man is believed to have been killed. Pickup 4th, `As a...'
DOC.TEXT: A British citizen reportedly was shot in Kuwait near the border with Saudi Arabia, the Foreign Office said Sunday. It is believed the man was killed, ``but we do not have confirmation,'' said Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave. ``If it's true, it's a horrific and tragic incident,'' said Waldegrave. He said Britain would not be deflected by threats against its citizens. The man was shot Saturday evening, according to reports that Waldegrave said came from others who crossed the border. As a signatory of the Geneva Convention, Iraq ``has a duty to let people go,'' Waldegrave said in an interview with BBC radio. ``Whether you call them hostages, whether you call them prisoners, whether you call them people who are simply not allowed their natural rights of free movement, we are _ with our colleagues in the European Community, and others such as the Russians _ bringing the maximum pressure to get out innocent people who are non-combatants,'' Waldegrave said. A Foreign Office spokesman said the report indicated that a British subject was shot ``some kilometers on the Kuwaiti side'' over the border. ``We have personal details and have notified next of kin. But we do not yet have a full account of the incident. We do not have confirmation of whether he is alive or dead,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We have demanded confirmation and clarification from the Iraqi authorities and made it clear that if the report is accurate, and if Iraqi troops were responsible, this is a barbaric incident, which will deeply shock the world community,'' the spokesman said. Roger Tomkys, a senior Foreign Office official, telephoned the Iraqi ambassador in London Saturday night to lodge a protest, the spokesman said. A number of British citizens crossed the Kuwait-Saudi border on Friday night. Some said the journey was surprisingly easy, but others reported moments of fright. Adrian King, who was among those returning to Britain on Sunday, said he had heard a burst of machine-gun fire. ``As we got to the border the Iraqis stopped one car that wasn't with our convoy, there was a short burst of machine-gun fire obviously to warn them to stop, but we decided to make a quick dash for it,'' said King, who crossed with his pregnant wife and two-year-old son. King said the convoy he was in encountered many Iraqi troops. ``We were absolutely sure we would be picked up. In fact on one occasion we were going so fast that I believe we caused one tank to go into another tank,'' he said. Others who crossed the border Friday night said they had encountered little interference from Iraqi troops. ``They were not bothering too much with Europeans,'' said Graham Robb of Aberdeen, Scotland, who arrived at Heathrow airport. Robb, who was among 14 people who crossed the border, said: ``We were stopped a couple of times, slowed down in our cars, but once they saw the white faces they gave us a smile and waved us on.'' Duncan Jones, a banker who returned to Gatwick airport Sunday morning, said the border crossing was ``surprisingly easy.'' ``I could not believe that we were allowed to drive past as many tanks and armored vehicles as we did,'' Jones said. Ramona Magee of San Diego said she crossed the border with a British friend

DOC.HEAD: Briton Reported Shot in Kuwait; Turkey Requests War Powers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8-10 pvs, `Britain's Foreign...of anonymity.' to UPDATE with Foreign Office saying Briton may have been killed. Pickup 11th, `After its...'
DOC.TEXT: Britain said Sunday that one of its citizens was reportedly shot in Kuwait near the border with Saudi Arabia, heightening concern for the safety of thousands of foreigners who have been trapped inside Iraq and Kuwait. For the second time in two days, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein urged his people to prepare for hardships that may result from international economic sanctions designed to punish his country for invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Iraqi News Agency said a group of pilots has offered to fly suicide missions against U.S. ships sent to the Persian Gulf as part of a multinational being deployed to defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack. In another development Sunday, Turkey's premier said he will ask Parliament for the power to declare a state of war and send armed forces into combat in the event of an escalation of the Persian Gulf crisis. Premier Yildirim Akbulut made the announcement before the start of an extraordinary session of Turkey's Parliament to discuss the crisis. In addition to massing troops on the Saudi border, Iraq reportedly sent soldiers to Turkey's border after it imposed economic sanctions on Iraq and effectively shut down pipelines that carry Iraqi oil through Turkish territory. Kuwaiti radio, in a transmission believed to originate in Saudi Arabia, said an envoy from President Bush delivered a message to Kuwait's ousted leaders in Saudi Arabia Sunday. The contents of the message were not divulged. Britain's Foreign Office said it believed the British man was killed in the reported attack Saturday evening, ``but we do not have confirmation.'' ``If it's true, it's a horrific and tragic incident,'' Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave told BBC radio. Waldegrave said the report came from unidentified people who had crossed the border recently. A Foreign Office spokesman said the report indicated that the British subject was shot ``some kilometers on the Kuwaiti side'' over the border. ``We have personal details and have notified next of kin. But we do not yet have a full account of the incident,'' said the spokesman. After its invasion of Kuwait, Iraq sealed its borders and those of Kuwait, trapping about 3,500 Americans and other foreigners. U.S. officials have expressed concern for their safety but have refused to call them hostages, saying negotiations with Iraq about their return are still under way. On Saturday, a 10-year-old California girl was one of 11 Americans who fled to safety in Jordan from Iraq. In a statement read on Baghdad radio and television on Sunday, Saddam urged women to organize their households and economize to help achieve victory. ``Liberation of Jerusalem, Mecca and Medina, this is your role,'' the Iraqi leader said in the message. Saddam on Friday declared a jihad, or holy war, on Saudi Arabia and Western nations moving forces to the Persian Gulf. The three cities are considered holiest to Moslems. In the statement, read by a government spokesman and monitored in Nicosia, Saddam said supplies were adequate to withstand the U.N.-imposed embargo. ``Train yourself and the family to take a serious posture in life where food and clothing will be much less, using only what is required for honorable living. The nation and future are threatened by the foreigner,'' he said. Saddam said Iraqis should be able to cut consumption of meat, food and clothing by half. ``Any lack of foodstuffs should not be a priority in our minds,'' Saddam said in the statement. ``Iraqis should concentrate on war, if it occurs.'' And Saddam warned against hoarding goods. ``We don't have to overload our tables. Let's be frugal, ascetic. We should not store any foodstuffs,'' he said in the statement. ``Don't take anything except what is needed for a day or week. Storage means shortage, a false one, not because supplies aren't there but because it has been stored.'' On Saturday, Iraq's Revolutionary Command Council warned that people selling food on the black market would be executed. The Iraqi News Agency said Arab pilots called ``The Group of Martry Joul Gamal'' said they were ready to carry out suicide attacks on U.S. ships dispatched to the gulf by foreign nations to enforce economic sanctions. In a telegram sent to Saddam, the group announced its ``determination to be martyrs in protection of Iraq and sanctities of the Arab and Islamic nation,'' the news agency reported. The United States, France and Britain have sent ships to the gulf region in an effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait. The U.S. has also committed an estimated 50,000 troops to the operation. Egypt and Morocco have also sent troops to Saudi Arabia to face Iraqi forces massed along that country's border with oil-rich Kuwait. However, in many Arab nations, most notably Jordan, there have been anti-U.S. protests and an outpouring of popular support for Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: Tamils Blamed For Slaying At Least 119 Moslem Villagers
DOC.TEXT: Tamil gunmen rampaged through five fishing villages, butchering Moslems in the street with machine-gun fire and machetes, military officials said Sunday. They said at least 119 people were slain. The killings were the latest in a round of intensifying ethnic violence that pits Tamil separatists against the Sinhalese-dominated government and Sinhalese and Moslem civilians. Although Moslems claim neutrality in the war, the government says Tamils suspect them of siding with the army. A Tamil politician said Saturday night's attacks were in retaliation for the killing of 33 Tamil villagers by Moslems earlier Saturday. But a spokesman for the Tamil Tigers guerrilla group denied responsibility for the killings. At least 450 villagers have been killed on the once-tranquil island nation's east coast in a wave of reprisal violence in the past nine days. The victims include 305 Moslems, 85 Tamils and 60 Sinhalese, according to military officials and politicians. In Eravur, one of the villages hit in Saturday night's attack, puddles of blood were on the sidewalk. Women implored visitors to help keep them safe, and young men surrounded army officers demanding weapons. ``They have killed everybody,'' one weeping woman told a delegation of Moslem politicians and soldiers. ``There is no one to look after us. Please don't leave.'' Led by Moslem religious leaders, villagers gathered up corpses in trucks for a mass burial. Residents and military officials on Sunday said at least 119 people were killed in the five villages and an additional 40 were injured. Brigadier Upali Seneviratne, the top army officer in the province, said at least 40 Tamil gunmen attacked the villages. ``They broke into three groups and shot at everybody in sight,'' he said. The dead included 29 women and 31 children, one of them a 9-day-old girl, he said. Residents said the attackers broke down doors and dragged villagers into the streets. After a 90-minute raid on Eravur, the gunmen moved to adjacent villages, military officials said. One of the villages is called Saddam Hussein, named after the Iraqi leader who sent construction aid several years ago. The villages are clustered north of Batticaloa on the east coast, about 125 miles east of Colombo. On Aug. 3, gunmen raided another eastern village and massacred 140 Moslems in two mosques. The incident set off a chain of killings. ``The two communities are on an annihilation spree. Nobody knows how many more will die before it all ends,'' said Mahalingam Savajilingam, a leader of the Tamil Eelam Liberation Organization, a former guerrilla group which gave up arms for politics. He said Saturday night's killings were carried out by the Tigers after 33 Tamils at a refugee camp, including eight patients in a hospital, were killed by Moslems using government-supplied weapons. ``This led to the Tamil Tigers attacking the villages...and killing innocent Moslems,'' he said. The Tamil Tigers, the militia fighting for an independent Tamil homeland in the north and east, deny the charges and say the killings are being carried out by government agents to discredit their organization. ``Why should we attack Moslems?'' said Lawrence Thilakar, a Tiger leader, in a telephone call Sunday to The Associated Press in Colombo. ``We need the fullest cooperation of the Moslem people, who are also supressed at the hands of the government.'' Thilakar spoke from London, where the Tigers maintain an office. ``This dangerous game being played by the government will not last long,'' he said. ``Very soon, the truth will come out.'' Tamil separatists, seeking an independent nation, resumed a 7-year-old war with the Sinhalese-dominated government on June 11 after a 13-month cease-fire. At least 3,200 combatants have been killed in the latest phase of fighting. Hundreds of civilians have also been killed, but there is no precise figure. Tamils, mainly Hindu, make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Sinhalese, overwhelmingly Buddhist, comprise 75 percent and Moslems 7 percent. An estimated 14,000 people have been killed since 1983 when Tamil rebels took up arms, claiming they were discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Five Bhutto Associates
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested five associates of ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, the first cases in what is expected to be a sweeping investigation of high-level corruption in her government, police said Sunday. Arrest orders also were issued for a sixth person, believed to be in hiding, police said. Earlier, Ms. Bhutto's mother left for London, authorities said. Nusrat Bhutto, 65, served as senior minister without portfolio in her daughter's Cabinet, a position that left her in charge of Pakistan when the prime minister was out of the country. She was also served as co-chairman of the Pakistan People's Party. Mrs. Bhutto boarded a Pakistan International Airlines flight for London shortly before dawn but a bomb hoax delayed the departure for nearly six hours, said an airline official, speaking on condition of anonymity. A family spokesman would not disclose the purpose of the trip, but party members said Mrs. Bhutto left for London for medical treatment. They gave no further details. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government on Aug. 6 on charges of political incompetence, mismanagement and corruption. Ms. Bhutto accused political opponents and the new caretaker government of planning a ``witch hunt'' against her family, former government and party stalwarts. The military-backed caretaker government headed by former opposition leader Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, denied the charges. ``No political arrests have been made and we do not intend to make any political arrests,'' Jatoi's press secretary Hussein Haqqani said. Late Saturday, police in the southern port city of Karachi, where Ms. Bhutto lives, arrested the five party workers. Officials said they are believed to be close associates of Asif Ali Zardari, who wed Ms. Bhutto in 1987 in a marriage arranged by her mother. During most of her 20 months in office, Ms. Bhutto fended off accusations that her husband was using his position for profit. Local newspapers dubbed him ``Mr. 10 Percent,'' a reference to accusations that he demanded commissions in return for lucrative contracts. Ms. Bhutto and Zardari have repeatedly denied the charges, and none has been proved. The arrested were: Ahmed Fahim Mogul, private secretary to Ms. Bhutto, Agha Sikunder, regional director of the Pakistan Narcotics Control Board, businessmen Fauzi Ali Kazmi and Dr. Zulfi Mirza. They were all arrested on corruption charges, police said. Khalid Mustafar Korai, special assistant to the former chief minister of Sindh Province, was arrested on gunrunning charges, police said. Haqqani said the new 12-member Cabinet is expected to soon establish tribunals to investigate corruption charges. Ms. Bhutto has said she will not appear before any tribunals appointed by her successors, but would appear before civilian courts.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Blacks Killed in Shooting
By SAHM VENTER
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Six men and three women were killed in gunfire in a hostel south of Johannesburg in what appeared to be a fight among black factions, police said Sunday. Police Capt. Eugene Opperman told the independent South African Press Association that attackers fired through the windows of two rooms in a black workers' hostel in Sebokeng Saturday night. Four men and three women were killed. Two other men died later in a hospital. Fifteen people were injured in the shooting. Police discovered several Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifles and bullet cartriges at the scene. Opperman told independent Radio 702 that the motive for the attack was unknown. ``We can only presume that it is differences among different black groups,'' he said. But he disputed a claim by a township resident that the violence was between supporters of the African National Congress and the conservative Zulu-based Inkatha party. The shooting follows violence in townships around Johannesburg between ANC supporters and other residents. At least 22 people were killed on July 22 in Sebokeng after armed Inkatha supporters clashed with township residents who had been warned by ANC leaders that Inkatha backers were planning to attack them. Earlier this month in Kagiso, east of Johannesburg, at least 12 people were killed in two days of violence between Inkatha backers and other residents. More than 5,000 blacks have died since 1986 in fighting between Inkatha and ANC supporters in the eastern province of Natal. Fears that the conflict may be spreading to other parts of the country were sparked in recent weeks by the fighting between Inkatha and opposing groups in areas around Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Movie Wins First Prize at Locarno Film Festival
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet film ``Waltz of Chance'' was awarded the Golden Leopard award at the Locarno Film Festival Saturday night. A British film ``The Reflecting Skin'' and the American film ``Metropolitan'' won second prizes. ``Waltz of Chance'' was directed by Svetlana Proskourina and featured unconventional scenes from the everyday life of a woman who lost faith in the future. The jury's decision drew mixed reactions when it was announced at Locarno's Piazza Grande. British director Philip Ridley, 30, was cited for ``The Reflecting Skin,'' which depicted the nightmares of a child. Whit Stillmann of the United States, won a Silver Leopard for ``Metropolitan,'' which featured a dialogue among youthful snobs. Winners of Bronze Leopards included Miklos Gurban, cameraman of a Hungarian entry, ``Scruple,'' and Emer McCourt, leading actress in ``Hush-A-Bye Baby'' produced in Northern Ireland. The festival, which drew a record audience of more than 100,000, was to end Sunday night with the gala screening of Proskourina's film.

DOC.HEAD: Updated Model of Malaysian Car Launched
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad on Sunday launched a more powerful version of Malaysia's Proton Saga passenger car. The new Proton Saga Megavalve comes with either a 1,300cc or 1,500cc engine. The new engines are 11 percent to 15 percent more powerful than the earlier models introduced three years ago, said Mohamed Nadzmi Mohamed Salleh, executive director of Edaran Otomobil Nasional. The Proton Saga is made in Malaysia in collaboration with Mitsubishi Motor Corp. of Japan. The engine, transmission and some other parts come from Japan, while the tires, batteries, wiring, seats and most other parts are made in Malaysia. Prices for the car range from about $10,000 for the 1,300cc model to about $13,000 for the 1,500cc Aeroback. ``Taking into account ... the additional features, the new Proton Saga is still the cheapest buy on the market,'' Nadzmi said.

DOC.HEAD: US to Intercept Iraqi Oil Shipments, Baker Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs; adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Sunday that the United States would intercept Iraqi oil shipments after the exiled Kuwaiti government asked world governments to enforce United Nations sanctions against Iraq. Baker declined to be specific about what the United States might do and said the plans would be developed over ``the next couple of days.'' He was careful about the language he used to describe any possible action. ``Let's not use the word blockade '' Baker said. ``Let's just say we have the legal basis for interdicting these things.'' In diplomatic parlance, a blockade is an act of war. ``I'll give you a word right now. Interdiction. I would suspect it would begin almost instantly ... now that Kuwait has made the request.'' Baker said the government of Kuwait that fled when Iraq invaded Aug. 2 had ``just requested of us and other nations support for enforcement of United Nations sanctions ... '' ``We now have the legal basis to enforce the sanctions,'' which call for an embargo on Iraqi exports and imports, Baker said. The United Nations Security Council approved a worldwide trade embargo on Iraq and Kuwait on Aug. 6. ``We're going to take measures that are necessary and proportional to enforce the United Nations standards now that we have a request,'' Baker said. Baker had been asked what the United States intends to do about an Iraqi tanker now off the coast of Saudi Arabia if it moves to claim Iraqi oil shipped by pipeline across Saudi Arabia. He did not comment on the ship specifically, but said that the United States planned to enforce the United Nations sanctions. A State Department spokesman said that U.S. officials gave no details about the Iraqi vessel. ``This was a very specific incident he (Baker) was raising to illustrate that we do have support from Kuwait and other countries to carry out the sanctions,'' said the spokesman, who asked not to be further identified. ``We don't know the name of the ship.'' Baker commented on the ABC television program ``This Week With David Brinkley.''

DOC.HEAD: `Notes of the Nightmare:' Woman Recounts Ordeal in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The writer, a 27-year-old bank employee in Kuwait, kept notes of her experiences after the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2. The Saudi Arabian woman and her family escaped from Kuwait, and she made her diary available to The Associated Press.

We witnessed the unthinkable: the invasion and conquest of Kuwait by fellow Arab troops of Iraq's President Saddam Hussein. We first encountered their ugly tanks on the streets of Kuwait City. Eight days later, we managed to escape to Bahrain. Here are my notes of the nightmare: Thursday, Aug. 2: As I approached the Gulf Bank, I saw many cars outside and people were inside to draw cash. Indians, Kuwaitis, Pakistanis, Eygptians, Palestinians, Americans, and others were outside the building. Some were yelling ``Go home, go home ... Iraq has invaded Kuwait.'' I drove home. Troops were streaming in and heavy vehicles rumbling down Istiklal (independence) boulevard. Friends called and told my family to get ready for war. How the hell do you get ready for war? Fill the bathtubs with water, buy as much canned food as possible. Buy water, call your kin and see if they have any plans to escape. Then, wait. We turned on the radio and took it along with mattresses down to the basement. Friday, Aug. 3: Whatever little sleep we could have we had. It was at that point that we heard bombs. Friends invited us to spend the night at their house. We went. The streets were empty, silent. There were about five radio sets tuned to the BBC, another on Voice of America, Saudi Arabia, Dubai, and Iraq (radio). It was horrible to hear what they (Iraqi radio) said, especially, since we knew that they were all lies ... that the Iraqis were in Kuwait to save its people ... Saturday, Aug. 4: We woke up to the sound of bombs. They were coming from an area called Kifan, where young Kuwaitis had obtained rifles and were harassing the Iraqis. We were proud of them. Friends called and said the Iraqis were looting shops and houses of rich people who were abroad. They said the Central Bank was looted too, along with car showrooms. We heard distant shelling and were told the Iraqis were trying to silence Kuwaiti guns at Shuwaikh. Sunday, Aug. 5: The Iraqis installed a new government, a joke of a government, a group of young Iraqis who tried over television to tell us they were Kuwaiti. Their accent betrayed their real nationality, despite their white robes and ghutra headgear. Wednesday, Aug. 8: We listened to the radio newscast. A friend called to see if we wanted to leave Kuwait. We refused. It was also the same evening that (President) Bush talked. I cried when Mr. Bush said he wanted the American people to pray for the men and women who will be fighting for the principles of freedom and democracy. I am Arab, and I felt bad thay we had to ask for foreign help to defend ourselves against an invasion by fellow Arabs. It was sad, but I understood it was necessary. An American friend of my father's had a heart attack. My sister and I went to him at hospital immediately. His condition improved but was anxious to be with the rest of his family. Thursday, Aug. 9: I went to hospital to visit the American and his wife and give them a radio set to listen to newscasts. When I returned home, a friend of ours, called Nasser, was there to offer us an escape plan, which we accepted. It pained our hearts to leave Kuwait. I am Saudi Arabian, but I have lived all my years here in this country. Friends told my father the Iraqis had rounded up foreigners, mainly American and British, and taken them to Baghdad as hostages. Shortly after 11 in the morning Nasser came and picked us up. We took what we can, some of our gold and important papers and left. My heart was tearing up as we drove down Fahaheel road, where two other families in their cars joined us. We were stopped at an Iraqi checkpoint. Nasser argued with one of the soldiers who let us through. We saw Iraqi soldiers near the border. Nasser stopped then turned right to the desert. The soldiers waved to us to get back. We ignored them. My heart was beating so fast I could not hear anything. We began to pray. We knew the Iraqis shoot first at the tires, then come and smash the cars and take occupants out. There were many destroyed cars along the border. We didn't what Iraqis did with the occupants. No shots were fired at us, but we couldn't get over fear. Nasser told us to start singing, to overcome fear. The three cars were running very fast. It took 15 minutes through the desert to reach the Saudi border, which we crossed into the Khafji region. We drove on to Nasser's house there. My father, uncle and aunt were there. We resumed driving, this time in safer areas. We crossed the 15-mile causeway on the (Persian) Gulf and entered Bahrain.

DOC.HEAD: World Leaders Turn Attention to Children
DOC.TEXT: The world's most powerful people will give their attention to the weakest at the World Summit for Children next month. Heads of state of 60 countries have agreed to meet at U.N. headquarters Sept. 29-30 to discuss ways of improving the lot of millions of children whose lives are threatened by poverty, disease or malnutrition. Officials of UNICEF, the United Nations Children's Fund, is organizing the summit. James P. Grant, executive director of UNICEF, said he hoped it would produce global acceptance of the idea that children have a ``first call'' on society's resources. He urged the national leaders to establish such goals for the 1990s as immunizing 80 percent of all children; reducing the number of children who die before age five by one-third, to 70 deaths per 1,000 live births, and providing safe drinking water for every child. The leaders also will be asked to commit themselves to eradicating polio and reducing measles by 90 percent over the decade. An international convention on children's rights has been ratified and will become effective Sept. 3. UNICEF said Bangladesh, Benin and Sudan ratified it Aug. 3, bringing the total to 22, two more than required. It sets minimum standards for children's health, education and protection from exploitation. In addition to addressing the direct needs of children, Grant sees the summit as a forum for discussing broader problems that effect them, such as debt relief. He described efforts by developing countries to pay their foreign debts as ``an economic hemorrhaging.'' ``In sub-Saharan Africa, for example, the economies are in such bad shape ... in part because of the debt crisis ... that there are inadequate funds for the social sector,'' he said in an interview at UNICEF headquarters in New York. The summit was proposed in the 1988 UNICEF report on ``The State of the World's Children.'' Canada, Egypt, Mali, Mexico, Pakistan and Sweden followed up in February with a formal call for the meeting. President Bush is among the national leaders who plans to attend. He will deliver the American president's annual annual address to the U.N. General Assembly the day after the summit. ``Children are relatively low on the priority list of most countries,'' Grant said. UNICEF estimates 8,000 children die every day from measles, whooping cough, tetanus and other diseases vaccination can prevent, and another 7,000 perish from being dehydrated by diarrhea. As many as 4,000 die each day because their mothers do not know how to breast feed them properly, the agency says. Most of these deaths occur in undeveloped countries. One goal of the summit, Grant said, is to get commitments from governments to educate parents about the importance of vaccinations, breast feeding and preventing. ``In the 1980s, many countries have demonstrated that it is possible to achieve many improvements in the health of children'' by marshaling government and the media to educate parents, Grant said. He said 10,000 children were saved every day because of such campaigns in the last decade, and another 20,000 can be saved each day in the 1990s if the world makes the commitment. The cost of preventing most child deaths would reach $2.5 billion a year by the end of the decade, UNICEF says, or 1 percent of the amount now spent on arms.

DOC.HEAD: Some AIDS-Infected Prostitutes Paid Not to Have Sex
DOC.TEXT: The state Health Department said Sunday it is paying several AIDS-infected prostitutes not to have sex. Dr. Charles Watson, director of Western Australia state's Disease Control division, said taxpayers were subsidizing ``less than five'' HIV-positive prostitutes by up to $80 a week as an incentive to keep them out of brothels and off the streets. Watson denied newspaper reports that the payments were as high as $240 a week. He said the payments continued for up to four weeks, until the male and female prostitutes were retrained for alternative work. He said the prostitutes could earn $400 to $800 a week on the streets. ``The money is clearly not a benefit arrangement. It is to handle emrgency situations or set up possibilities for retraining into another job,'' Watson said. He said the money was paid by the Support, Information, Educational and Referral Association from AIDS Council funding, which comes mainly from the Health Department. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is a disease caused by the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV. The disease attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. The virus is most often transmitted through sexual contact. Other means of transmission include transfusions of tainted blood or blood products, and the sharing of contaminated hypodermic needles or syringes by drug abusers.

DOC.HEAD: Presley Fans Brace for Imitators, Singing Relatives
DOC.TEXT: The Elvis Presley faithful are gathering again for their annual pilgrimage on the anniversary of his death. A week-long lineup of 13th anniversary events includes dances and musical shows, a Presley impersonator contest and a candlelight procession past his grave. A 4-year-old Presley imitator is to perform at an ``Elvis Nostalgia Concert,'' and a four-member band billed as Elvis cousins planned a show called ``Kin to the King.'' Presley fell dead on a bathroom floor at his Graceland mansion Aug. 16, 1977. For several years afterward, the anniversary gatherings were informal, but that began to change when the ground floor of Graceland opened for public tours in 1982. Now, the anniversary is the focal point of ``Elvis International Tribute Week.'' Graceland, the white-columned Georgian residence Presley bought in 1957, is expected to draw more than 30,000 visitors over the anniversary week. It attracts more than 600,000 visitors a year and supports a tourist complex that includes museums and souvenir shops. Graceland crowds often include fans with jet-black pompadours, long sideburns and bespangled bell-bottomed trousers. For anniversary week, the Elvis dress-alikes are especially common. The single largest gathering each year is a candlelight procession to Presley's grave beside Graceland. The procession begins at 10 p.m. Wednesday. It generally takes participants four to five hours to file past the grave in single file. Presley fans have formed more than 280 clubs around the world, including ones in Zimbabwe and Moscow, said Patsy Andersen, Graceland's fan club coordinator. Many of the clubs send members to Memphis for the anniversary week. ``We've got clubs coming from Hungary, from Germany, Brazil, Japan, England, Denmark and from all over the United States,'' Ms. Andersen said. While most of the Presley fare is promoted by Graceland, one of the most popular events, the impersonator contest, has grown on its own at a Memphis nightclub called Bad Bob's Vapors. It runs throughout the week with the winner drawing a trip for two to Cancun, Mexico. The 4-year-old contest generally draws performers who base their acts on Presley's bespangled jumpsuit period, said Jackie Franklin, the show's manager. Though the performers follow each other closely on stage and often sing the same songs, particularly ``My Way'' and ``American Trilogy,'' the audience is generally kind. ``No one ever complains,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Hesitation May Signal Lying By Job Applicants, Study Suggests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `MPORT' in 16th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: People take a split second longer to lie than to tell the truth when asked about themselves, which may help identify dishonesty by job applicants, suggests a study presented Sunday. Questions about illegal drug use and employment history showed the effect most clearly when study participants answered true-false questions on a computer. If further research bears out its promise, the effect may be useful in screening applicants for jobs in law enforcement or private security, or for security clearances, said study co-author Michael McDaniel. While it could not prove deception by itself, it might signal areas for extra scrutiny in background checks, he said. He spoke in an interview before presenting the work at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association. McDaniel, a psychologist who consults on human resources issues, said he did the work independently of his employer, Booz-Allen & Hamilton Inc. of Bethesda, Md. The same is true for study co-author Howard Timm of the Defense Personnel Security Research and Education Center in Monterey, Calif., McDaniel said. Other psychologists cautioned that the study was limited by several factors, but said it contributed to an area that needs further research. The experiment involved 198 students in a criminal justice class, most of whom hoped to work in law enforcement or security jobs. They completed a 131-item true-false test, which they were told was being evaluated as a tool for screening applicants for security-related jobs. They were told to answer the questions as if they were taking it for a job they wanted. Later, they were asked to complete it again, but this time to answer as honestly as possible. Confidentiality was assured. Whenever a participant answered a question differently the second time from the first time, he was assumed to have been lying the first time. Overall, for honest answers, participants took an average of 4.03 seconds from the time the question appeared on the screen to the time they punched a key in response. Dishonest answers required an additional three-fifths of a second. Lying on the 12 drug use questions, such as whether one had gotten into a significant amount of trouble from cocaine use, took an average of 1.1 seconds longer than telling the truth. The difference for the 12 employment questions, such as whether one had been fired for poor performance, was .94 second. Smaller differences were observed for other categories of questions on such topics as alcohol use, crime, and possessing such unlikely virtues as never getting angry. McDaniel said he has not yet determined how to analyze the results of such a test in a job-screening situation. Analysis would have to account for the fact that people have different average reaction times to questions, and that some questions take longer to answer than others, he said. Terry Mitchell, a psychologist who has done similar work, said the new paper will ``stimulate attention to an area of research that's very important.'' But Mitchell, president of MPORT Management Solutions in San Diego, Calif., said deception does not always take longer than honest responses. A person who simply punches in answers wihout thinking about the questions, or who has been coached on what answers to give, will take less time, he said. He also cautioned that while response delays might suggest inaccurate answers to particular questions, that is different from determining whether a person is basically honest. Margaret McManus, who develops personnel selection tests at the Life Insurance Marketing and Research Association in Hartford, Conn., called the work a ``reasonably well done, interesting study.'' But she said it included relatively few participants, and that they were students rather than real job applicants. More work is needed on the topic, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Officers Say Carriers May Be Key to Defusing Aggression in Mideast
LaserPhoto LA9
DOC.TEXT: The presence of U.S. aircraft carriers in the Middle East could help stop Iraqi aggression, but the massive floating airports could be vulnerable to chemical warfare, officers aboard the USS Nimitz say. The nuclear-powered carrier, performing flight operations off the California coast, has cruised the Middle East and the Persian Gulf area before. In 1981, two of its aircraft shot down Libyan planes over the Gulf of Sidra. One sailor said he hoped the ship would go to the Middle East. ``I would like to see something done,'' said Chris Szymanski, 20, a Bedford, Mich., native who works in the galley. ``I would like to see the Nimitz go, but I know that some of the people would not like to see the Nimitz go because of their girlfriends or their marriage.'' But the Nimitz, which left its home port of Bremerton, Wash., last week, had no orders to go to the Middle East. Officers aboard the Nimitz say their sister carriers could be a deterrent to Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein and his million-man military. The carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower and its flotilla recently crossed the Red Sea into the Indian Ocean. The carrier Independence and its 13 escort and support ships are in the northern Arabian Sea, and the Saratoga and its 15-ship battle group are en route to the Mediterranean. Over the weekend, the Pentagon declined to comment on a number of reports that the aircraft carrier USS Kennedy would be sent to the Mideast from Norfolk, Va., where it is being supplied for a new duty cruise. The carriers can each carry at least 5,000 men and more than 70 aircraft, including A-6E and FA-18 attack bombers and F-14A Tomcats. They also carry anti-submarine Sea King helicopters and E-2C Hawkeyes, whose rotating radar domes provide early warning capabilities. The ships also have their own missile defense systems. ``The carrier has a long arm to deliver weapons, to hit targets, and it can move around,'' said Cmdr. Bruce Ross, an officer in the Nimitz's Combat Defense Center, the nerve center of a carrier. With four catapults, a carrier can launch an aircraft every 30 seconds. Radar jammers would make it difficult for an enemy fleet to find the carriers. ``I don't know how many wars and how many conflicts have been prevented in the past 20 years by having a carrier battle group present off the coast or in a position to strike potential adversaries,'' said Nimitz Capt. Robert C. Williamson, a 27-year Navy veteran. ``In this particular case, I don't think we desire to have a conflict or any expansion of the warfare that has taken place right now, but I do know we will defend (Saudi Arabia) militarily,'' he said. Iraq used chemical weapons in its war with Iran, and U.S. ground troops are equipped for defense against them. Nimitz officials say carriers also can be susceptible to chemical attack. ``If you want to neutralize a carrier, the best thing that (an enemy) can do is to use chemical weapons,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Tom Tanner, a combat damage control assistant who helps train sailors on chemical warfare defense. The ship frequently has drills during which crew members don cumbersome masks. The sailors also are equipped with rubber boots and gloves and charcoal-lined pants and hooded tops. ``By just threatening a chemical attack _ and having to get your guys onto the flight decks with their suits _ they've met their mission,'' Tanner said. ``It puts you in a position that cuts down your effectiveness.'' But the Nimitz's captain minimized the possibility of Iraq harming a U.S. Navy battle group. ``I don't feel very threatened by Iraqis at all when we're operating in the Arabian Sea,'' Williamson said. ``If I were (Saddam), I'd quit right now,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Karelia Declares Sovereignty from Russia
DOC.TEXT: The autonomous republic of Karelia on the border with Finland has declared sovereignty from both the Soviet Union's largest republic and from the central Soviet government, Tass reported. Karelia, which includes a large amount of one-time Finnish territory, is one of 20 ``autonomous republics'' located within the 15 Soviet republics. Russia, in which Karelia is located, is the largest and most populous republic. Karelia, home to 700,000 people, declared that its constitution and laws take precedence over those of Russia and the Soviet Union, the official Soviet news agency said Saturday. But Karelia softened the declaration by agreeing to voluntarily cede some of its powers to both. Karelia's declaration also states the right to independently decide matters of international relations, and to change its legal status. Tass said the declaration specifically emphasizes that it is not intended to drive a wedge between the governments of Karelia and Russia, led by reformer Boris N. Yeltsin. Eight of the union republics have declared some form of sovereignty from the Kremlin. Lithuania has taken the strongest step, declaring its independence on March 11.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Princess Diana and her two young sons arrived on this Mediterranean island Sunday to join Prince Charles for a brief vacation as guests of the Spanish royal family. Charles, who has been staying with friends on the Spanish island since Wednesday, picked up his family at the airport in a van driven by Princess Elena, the eldest daughter of Spain's King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia. Also making the trip to meet the flight were Spain's Princess Cristina and Sofia's brother, the former King Constantine of Greece. This is the third time in four years that Charles, Diana and Princes William and Harry have spent part of their summer holiday at the Spanish royal summer residence, Marivent Palace. In 1988, the Spanish and British press published pictures of a bikini-clad Diana diving into the Mediterranean off the royal yacht Fortuna.

A new television series is bringing Burt Reynolds back to Southern California, with the actor renting a home in the upscale Bel-Air section for $40,000 a month. Reynolds and his wife, actress Loni Anderson, have spent most of the past year in Florida, where Reynolds has long owned a ranch. But the actor, who sold his house in the Holmby Hills section of Los Angeles last year, has taken a year's lease on new digs in Bel-Air as he works on his new show, said Bobbi Ward of Asher Dann and Associates, who represented him in negotiating the lease. Reynolds is the star and co-executive producer of ``Evening Shade,'' which airs this fall. The CBS show brings a former pro football player back to his hometown to raise a family. Ms. Ward said Reynolds leased the home without his wife's knowledge, but ``when she saw it, she loved it.'' The 15,000-square-foot furnished house has eight bedrooms and 11 bathrooms and sits on a two-acre compound with a tennis court and swimming pool.

Developer Donald Trump claims he's making a killing now that people think he has no money. ``It's good for me to be thought of as poor right now,'' he said in the September issue of Vanity Fair magazine. ``You wouldn't believe some of the deals I am making. I guess I have a perverse personality. ... I've really enjoyed the last few weeks.'' Trump says he's not upset at being dropped from Forbes magazine's list of the world's richest men and blames it on a run-in he had with the magazine's late owner, Malcolm Forbes. The magazine, which last put Trump's net worth at $1.7 billion, lowered that estimate to $500 million in April. ``(I've) been expecting this attack from Forbes,'' he said. ``You know why? Malcolm Forbes got thrown out of the Plaza by me! ... You'll read about it in my new book. And I didn't throw him out because he didn't pay his bill.'' Trump also said he is more popular than ever despite the bad press he's been getting about his marital woes and cash problems. And that popularity has rubbed off on the two women most often linked with him: his estranged wife, Ivana, and his alleged mistress, Marla Maples. ``I've made a lot of satellites ... whether it's Marla or Ivana,'' Trump said. ``Marla can do any movie she wants to now. Ivana can do whatever she wants.''

Maggie Kuhn, the 85-year-old activist for the elderly who founded the Gray Panthers, received an honorary doctorate from Northern Illinois University. Kuhn was given a Doctor of Humane Letters degree in recognition of her work in fighting against age discrimination, the university said. ``When I turned 80, I made a solemn vow to myself that I would try to do something outrageous at least once a week,'' Kuhn said at Saturday's ceremony. ``The current and immediate past administrations have given me endless opportunities to do so.'' In 1970, Kuhn and five friends formed the Gray Panthers, which has lobbied against Social Security cuts and fought for rent control and better health care for senior citizens. The organization has grown to more than 70,000 members.

Former Mayor Ed Koch will talk about anything. Except money. The former mayor is out on the national talk-circuit, doing daily radio commentaries, dishing out opinions on weekly television news-shows and even talking up a diet drink. But as far as his earnings, mum's the word. ``I never discuss money. It's gauche,'' he said in a recent interview. Koch is expected to earn nearly $2 million this year, including $1.6 million from speaking fees of $20,000 a speech, the Daily News said Sunday. That's a far cry from the $130,000 salary he was making when he left office last year after 12 years on the job.

Singer William Lee Golden says he still knows very little about why he was voted out of the Oak Ridge Boys' country music group three years ago. The other three members of the group ousted him from the quartet in March 1987, citing friction among band members. He was replaced by Steve Sanders. ``We've still never had a meeting over that dismissal,'' said Golden. He now works as a solo performer and with his two sons, Rusty and Chris. The Oak Ridge Boys' biggest hit when Golden was with them was ``Elvira.'' The group's ``No Matter How High'' was No. 1 on the country music charts in February.

DOC.HEAD: How Much to Dispatch U.S. Troops? Maybe $440 Million a Month
DOC.NOTE: EDS: The numbers in this estimate differ from those in the AM-News Digest, a9990. These estimates are based on deployment of 50,000 troops, which is the figure used by the analysts.
DOC.TEXT: Sending U.S. military forces to Saudi Arabia will cost an estimated $300 million to $440 million a month, defense analysts say. And like everybody else, the Pentagon will feel the bite of fuel bills driven up by the crisis in the Middle East. Higher oil bills could add billions of dollars to Pentagon spending, other analysts say _ affecting not only troops deployed in the Persian Gulf but U.S. military operations everywhere. Figuring the cost of the deploying troops to Saudi Arabia has been a slippery exercise for analysts inside and outside the government. Many were reluctant to give even a ballpark figure because there are so many unknown factors. For one, the number of troops being sent is still uncertain _ 50,000 or 250,000. And no one knows how long they will stay. Besides, some costs already are being paid _ salaries, food, supplies, fuel and maintenance _ and any increases caused by the deployment are difficult to measure in advance. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said simply, ``I have no idea how much it's costing a day.'' President Bush sidestepped the issue after announcing he had sent Americans into the Persian Gulf to help defend Saudi Arabia. ``Whatever it is, we're going to have to pay it,'' he said. Lawrence Korb, a former assistant secretary of defense who is now a defense analyst with the Brookings Institute, estimated the cost at $10 million a day, or $300 million a month. His estimate is based on the deployment of 50,000 people and three carrier task forces. It gives the costs above what the Pentagon would spend anyway in salaries and other expenses for peacetime operations. The Center for Defense Information, a group of retired military officials that often has criticized U.S. military spending as excessive, estimated that deploying 50,000 troops would cost about $440 million a month above normal military expenses. And if the U.S. sends as many as 250,000 troops, the additional monthly cost could rocket to $1.69 billion, according to the center's study. Another analyst, a House staffer who works on defense issues also estimated the cost ``in the hundreds of millions.'' That's just to maintain defensive positions. If shooting starts, costs will spiral. Ammunition is expensive and damage to ships, planes, tanks and other equipment _ not to mention people _ is incalculable. Maintenance costs are likely to skyrocket, too. The Saudi desert sands present ``hideous conditions'' for equipment, said a Senate budget analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The maintenance costs are going to be enormous,'' the Senate analyst said. But perhaps the biggest potential cost is fuel. Consumers already are paying more at the gas pump. For the Pentagon, every penny per gallon increase adds $100 million in defense spending, Korb said. ``Fuel costs could run in the billions,'' said the House staffer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. House and Senate budget analysts say the Pentagon is working on cost projections for the operation but has not yet sent them to Congress. Analysts say the initial costs can be handled by transferring money between accounts, skimping in some places to cover the operations. After that, the Pentagon may have to go back to Congress and ask for more money. All this is comes while the administration is fighting with congressional budgetmakers to limit what Congress cuts from defense. Saudi Arabia said it is prepared to help defray some of the costs of maintaining a U.S.-dominated multinational force in the kingdom. Asked if the Saudis would pay for the fuel used by U.S. naval and air forces, Saudi Ambassador Prince Bandar Bin Sultan responded: ``I can't imagine us disagreeing with that point.'' Elaborating on that, a Saudi source, speaking on condition on anonymity, said the Saudis were willing to pick up other costs but were concerned that doing so would create the appearance of hiring mercenaries to protect their borders.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leader Demands Release of 15 Convicted Bombers
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A senior Shiite Moslem leader appealed Sunday for Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to release 15 Shiite Moslems imprisoned for the bombings of the U.S. and French Embassies in Kuwait. The release of the imprisoned men has long been a key demand by Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, a Shiite group which holds American journalist Terry A. Anderson and educator Thomas Sutherland as hostages. ``The 15 (jailed Shiites) reportedly have been moved to Baghdad and they should be freed,'' said Hussein Musawi. He heads a pro-Syrian wing of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, Iran's main ally in Lebanon and an umbrella for several hostage-holding factions. ``The demand of the hostage-holders still stands as well as other demands,'' Musawi said in a telephone interview from his home in the eastern town of Baalbek. ``The United States, Britain and Germany are all aware of the (kidnappers') demands. There are interests for the Moslems in Lebanon and elsewhere in the Middle East that these countries should take into consideration,'' Musawi said. He did not elaborate. The hostages held in Lebanon are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, a Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, has been held the longest. He was abducted March 16, 1985. Asked whether the kidnappers would harm the hostages because of the U.S. military deployment in Saudi Arabia, Musawi said: ``If the Moslems are cornered by a new U.S. aggression, they will act. I don't want to go into details.'' Seventeen Shiite Moslems were convicted for the Dec. 1983 embassy bombings in Kuwait that left five people dead and 86 wounded. Of the 17 men convicted in the attack, three were given death sentences, seven were sentenced to life, four were given 15-year terms, one was sentenced to 10 years and two were released after serving two years. One of those sentenced to death is Mustapha Youssef Badreddin, a cousin and brother-in-law of Imad Mughniyeh, said to be the leader of Islamic Jihad. One of the men sentenced to life is Hassan Youssef Musawi, Hussein Musawi's cousin. Hussein Musawi, who branded Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``a Satan, not a hero,'' was instrumental in the release of American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed in April. ``If Saddam is truly anti-American, then he should set these 15 men free at once,'' Musawi said. There were conflicting reports about the fate of the 15 convicts in Kuwait after Iraq's invasion of the oil-rich Arab state on Aug. 2. One report said Iraqi troops shot and killed them. Another said they were removed from Kuwait to a Baghdad prison. Kuwait had identified the bombers as members of the pro-Iranian Dawa party, an Iraqi group seeking to overthrow Saddam. Musawi condemned the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the U.S. military buildup in the area. ``The Moslem youths should not be deceived. They should confront Saddam's aggression without cooperation with the great Satan (America), which also should be confronted by suicide attacks,'' Musawi added. ``Saddam is a Satan, not a Moslem leader. The one who waged war against the Islamic republic (Iran) and Syria and who unleashed chemical weapons against the Kurds is not a hero but a Satan.''

DOC.HEAD: High-Paid Executive Chairing California Panel on Legislative Pay
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Deukmejian selected one of the highest-paid private executives in the state to head a new commission to decide how much California's lawmakers should earn. Claude S. Brinegar, executive vice president of Union Oil Co. of California, earned more than $1.6 million last year, according to a report last week in the San Jose Mercury News. But Brinegar, who was U.S. secretary of transportation for two years, said in a recent interview that his current salary will not affect his decisions on the legislative salary commission. He's known ``low salaries'' too, he said: ``When I went to the U.S. government as secretary of transportation, I took a Cabinet post at $60,000, and I lived on it.'' As chairman, Brinegar will preside over a panel appointed to judge the adequacy of legislators' current salary of $40,816 a year. The California Citizens Compensation Commission was created after voters passed an initiative package designed to halt ethics abuses.

DOC.HEAD: Flutists From Afar Flaunt Flutes At Fling
DOC.TEXT: As many as 2,500 members of the National Flute Association are expected to come to the Twin Cities for the organization's 18th annual convention this week. Irene Pruzan, marketing director of the more than 4,000-member flute association and herself a flutist, said there are 1 million flute players in the United States. ``I know this sounds self-serving,'' she said, ``but I think of flutists as the most intelligent and creative of instrumentalists.'' ``Our association has more members than any other instrumental organization,'' she added. ``When clarinetists get together, there's hardly 200 people there.'' The convention will consist of concerts, competitions, panels, workshops and exhibits. Among the international participants will be Soviet flutist Oleg Kudriashov of the Kiev Philharmonic and Conservatory, Benoit Fromanger from Paris and Andras Adorjan from Germany. Specialists in the baroque flute will also perform, along with jazz and ethnic flute players from the United States and Ireland and musicians from orchestras such as the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the Chicago Symphony, the Boston Symphony and the Minnesota Orchestra. Professional flutist Steve Kujala's performance Friday at Central Lutheran Church as part of the convention will include some improvisation. The purpose of the concert is to highlight the link between 18th century music and jazz. ``Keyboard players back then had to fill out the bass with chords,'' Kujala said. ``Soloists would improvise with cadenzas and embellishments. There was far more improvisation then than now, at least in the classical world.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury in Pilots' Trial Weighing Smooth Flight Against Blood-Alcohol Evidence
DOC.TEXT: If three former Northwest Airlines flight officers are to be found guilty of flying while intoxicated, jurors must conclude they were impaired by alcohol despite their apparently solid performance. With the third week of testimony in the federal trial to start Monday, defense attorneys have demonstrated that Flight 650 on March 8 from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis-St. Paul was smooth despite freezing drizzle. ``Overall, I don't see any area that I can point to and say they fell short,'' said Robert Collette, an expert defense witness who reconstructed the flight based on tape-recorded communications between the crew and air traffic controllers. Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega has not uncovered any problems with the flight. But she has hard evidence that alcohol was lingering in the pilots' bodies from a night of heavy drinking which ended for the captain within about seven hours of the flight. Capt. Norman Lyle Prouse has admitted drinking more than 15 rum and colas and a waitress at the Speak Easy restaurant and lounge in Moorhead has testified that First Officer Robert Kirchner and Flight Engineer Joseph Balzer shared seven pitchers of beer. Kirchner and Balzer left the bar about 10:30 p.m., about an hour before Prouse, she testified. In blood-alcohol tests performed two hours after the Boeing 727 safely landed 91 passengers at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, Prouse showed a blood-alcohol content of 0.13 percent _ more than legal limit for driving cars in Minnesota and other states. Each pilot is charged with operating an aircraft while under the influence of alcohol. The case marks the first time that commercial pilots have been tried under the 1988 federal law provision prohibiting operation of a common carrier while under the influence of alcohol. However, unlike state drunken driving laws, the federal law does not specify an illegal blood-alcohol content. ``The issue is not what his condition was the night before or what his alcohol content was the next day,'' Prouse's lawyer, Peter Wold, told jurors. ``The government must show their abilities were impaired. Based on all the evidence, we will show you their abilities were very good.'' De la Vega's final witness, behavioral scientist Herbert Moskowitz, said tests have proven that all humans are impaired by alcohol when their blood-alcohol content hits a mere 0.01 percent _ the equivalent of half a beer. He said ``significant impairment'' of vision, information processing and short-term memory occur in all people beginning at blood-alcohol levels of 0.02 percent and 0.03 percent. ``Any amount of alcohol reduces or decreases your ability to perform,'' Moskowitz testified. ``There's no way you can look at somebody and tell that their brain is operating more slowly, but it is when you have alcohol in your system.'' Prouse agreed under cross-examination Thursday that it's dangerous to fly within eight hours of drinking. But he said he did not believe he was endangering any lives when he ignored a caution from an FAA inspector in Fargo not to fly. ``I'd think it was dangerous if I was impaired,'' Prouse said. Prouse, 51, said he was accustomed to heavy drinking because he is an alcoholic. Part of his defense is that he has a high tolerance for alcohol that makes it harder for him to get drunk. A bar patron reported the three crew members to the Federal Aviation Administration. They were arrested when the plane landed in the Twin Cities. Northwest fired them for breaking the company rule of drinking within 12 hours of flying, and the FAA has revoked their licenses. If convicted, the pilots face a maximum 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Former Schoolgirl To Get $120,000 For `Bureaucracy At Its Worst'
DOC.TEXT: The federal government has agreed to pay $120,000 to a crippled Navajo woman who experienced what a judge called ``bureaucracy at its worst'' after being barred by a Bureau of Indian Affairs high school. The settlement, approved last week by U.S. District Judge Carl Muecke, calls for Lorraine Begay to be paid $20,000 immediately and $100,000 over the next 15 years. In addition, it calls for $100,000 to be paid to her lawyers, who have worked on the case for six years. Ms. Begay, 23, suffers from progressive arthritis and has to use a wheelchair. She had sued individual employees of the BIA because she was barred by law from suing the federal government directly. The BIA boarding school at Many Farms on the Navajo reservation never installed a wheelchair ramp or special toilet she would have needed to attend. The modifications would have cost no more than a few thousand dollars at most, according to court records, and were supposed to have been made under a federal law mandating access for the handicapped. School officials give conflicting reasons as to why the work wasn't done. The government paid for private lawyers to represent the BIA employees but said initially that it would not pay any judgment if Ms. Begay won in court. Because none of the individual BIA employees was rich, that left Ms. Begay's lawyers looking at the possibility they could win a big judgment and then be unable to collect it. Muecke, in pre-trial hearings, urged both sides to settle and hinted strongly that the government should pay. At one point, addressing a defense claim that only top-level officials in Washington were at fault and that Ms. Begay should have sued them, Muecke replied: ``I find that rather astonishing. I find that bureaucracy at its worst.'' Ms. Begay's struggle began about 10 years ago, after juvenile arthritis confined her to a wheelchair. She wanted to attend the Many Farms boarding school in northeastern Arizona with her brothers and sisters. The BIA offered to send her to special schools for the handicapped, hundreds of miles away. Ms. Begay refused, saying she did not have the kind of mental handicaps that the other schools were set up to accommodate. ``I am a regular child and want to be in school with all my brothers and sisters,'' she wrote at one point. Ms. Begay, who lives with her mother in a house with no electricity or runnign water, enrolled instead in a day school 10 miles over bumpy roads from her home. She graduated from high school two years late, largely because of absences attributed to her illness. Ms. Begay's telephone rang unanswered Saturday and Sunday. She said in a recent letter to one of her lawyers that she was glad not to have to go to court. James Loss, who heads the civil division of the U.S. Attorney's Office in Phoenix, referred the call to the Justice Department, saying lawyers there had made the settlement. Frank Kelly, a Justice Department spokesman, said Sunday that his agency would have no immediate comment.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Many Southern California Workers Want to Quit to Be With Kids
DOC.TEXT: Seventy-nine percent of mothers and 39 percent of fathers in Orange and Los Angeles counties would quit their jobs if they could to stay home with their kids, according to a poll released Sunday. The survey, commissioned by the Los Angeles Times, indicates that Southern California families are adopting a ``new realism'' about the hardships family life faces when both parents are full-time wage earners, said a social historian. ``We've reached a time when we're more realistic of what the costs are of full-time employment for two-earner families,'' said Barbara Dafoe Whitehead, who is a consultant to the Chicago-based Public Policy Association. The telephone poll of 1,000 families was conducted by Mark Baldassare & Associates July 19-23 and has a margin of error of 3 percent to 5 percent, the Times reported. Eighty-seven percent of mothers and 80 percent of fathers rated family and children as very important, yet many said they cannot find time to have dinner with their families regularly. Fifty-seven percent of fathers and 55 percent of mothers also said they feel guilty about spending too little time with their children. Many parents interviewed by the newspaper reflected those statistics in more personal ways. ``I've cried on my way to work many times,'' said Benay Clark of Los Angeles. She said her 2{-year-old daughter, Mallory, often cries, clings to her and asks why she has to have a job. ``Every day is a challenge and a balancing act,'' said single mother Linda Sonnonstine of Irvine. Sonnonstine, 42, changed jobs in order to spend more time with her teen-age son. Fifty-one percent of the men interviewed said they believe their work interferes with their parental responsibilities either a lot or some, and 28 percent said they believe their parental responsibilities are hurting their careers either a lot or some. Thirty-nine percent of the women believe their careers are interfering with rearing their children a lot or some, and 41 percent believe their parenting duties are hurting their careers. Sixty-four percent of the fathers and 72 percent of the mothers confided that they worry about whether they are good parents.

DOC.HEAD: Beach Closed After Ammunition Found _ Some May Be From Civil War Era
DOC.TEXT: A one-mile stretch of beach was temporarily closed after at least 28 shells _ some of which may date back to the Civil War _ were discovered in sand dredged from the Chesapeake Bay. Police and fire officials closed Buckroe Beach on Saturday after a man looking for valuables with a hand-held metal detector found four 11-inch-long shells. At least 28 shells have been found since Wednesday, when a Norfolk Dredging employee discovered three shells along the beach. ``Some are missing the nose part or the fuse part. All of them still have the explosive material inside the shell,'' Fire Battalion Chief Richard C. Blakeslee said Sunday. Police officers guarded the beach area and shooed away would-be explorers until a two-man team from Langley Air Force Base arrived late Saturday to dispose of the shells. On Sunday morning, officials armed with metal detectors unearthed eight shells during a sweep of the beach, police said. Officials reopened a major portion of the beach Sunday afternoon. Much of the ammunition is World War II vintage, but officials said some dates back to World War I and some contained traces of a powder that was used in Civil War artillery. Blakeslee said most of the shells were probably dredged up from an area that was previously used for target practice. Tech. Sgt. S.P. Temme of Langley's Explosive Ordnance Disposal Unit said it was unlikely that the shells would explode, unless they were dropped on their nose. Blakeslee said some of the shells probably could cause extensive of damage. ``These were designed to take aircraft down,'' he said. ``Once that black powder portion dries, they can be capable of doing their job for up to 200 years.'' The shells were dredged along with tons of sand from the Chesapeake Bay about two miles offshore, and pumped through a 22-inch wide steel pipe onto the beach. Sand is being dredged from the bay as part of a nearly $1 million beach replenishment project that began Aug. 3. The Air Force base was unable to offer its larger mine detectors because they were being transferred to the Middle East to help the U.S. defend Saudi Arabia from a possible attack by Iraq, Temme said.

DOC.HEAD: US Commander Says Troops Alert to Terrorists
With AM-US Iraq Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The commander of the U.S. military effort in Saudi Arabia said Sunday that his troops would be on guard against terrorists as well as Iraqi guns and gas. Describing the massive movement of troops and equipment overseas as a ``totally awesome'' undertaking that is moving ahead of schedule, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf also said that the combined forces in place in the Middle East could withstand an Iraqi attack if one occurred now. ``I would never tell you that the American forces that are there are 100 percent out of harm's way,'' Schwarzkopf told reporters at a briefing at United States Central Command headquarters on this base near Tampa. But, he said, ``We have built up a great deal of force over there now ... and if they do make an attack they are going to pay a price for it.'' Although American ground forces are outnumbered at the moment, U.S. air and naval power could neutralize any Iraqi attack, Schwarzkopf said. He added in response to a question that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's call for Arab world resistance to the U.S. presence would force troops to be on the lookout. ``There are several terrorist organizations that have found haven in Iraq and I have every expectation that they're going to be asked to do something,'' he said. ``We're paying attention.'' In October 1983, more than 200 Marines and sailors who were part of an international peacekeeping force were killed by a terrorist truck bomb in Beirut. U.S. service members also have been the victims of terrorist assaults in Western Europe. Schwarzkopf opened his briefing by describing the logistical challenge of transporting U.S. troops and equipment to the Middle East, 7,000 miles by air and 12,000 miles by sea from the East Coast. Airlifting one heavy division would take 1,538 loads aboard a C-141 transport and another 269 loads aboard a C-5 transport, the largest aircraft in the world. For that reason, he said a lot of equipment was being shipped by sea. ``The magnitude of this task, to quote my teen-agers, is `totally awesome','' Schwarzkopf said. Schwarzkopf said the Iraqis were continuing to move reinforcements into Kuwait. Those forces were taking up defensive positions and some were ``right down literally on'' the Kuwait-Saudi border, he said. Schwarzkopf said that the Iraqi troops had taken a similar defensive posture before invading Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``There's no question about the fact that they have dug in right now for a strong defense,'' the general said. But he added: ``They have the capability to do just about anything they want to.'' Schwarzkopf said he was confident U.S. troops could perform well in the desert climate even if Saddam unleashed his arsenal of chemical weapons. ``It's tough, sure, but it's not impossible. It's nowhere near impossible.'' Asked whether he expected a chemical attack, Schwarzkopf said:``Given their record in the Iran-Iraq war I would never discount that possibility ...
