We're prepared for everything.'' He said Iraq has been calling up reserves but that its best troops were those that invaded Kuwait and are still there. Schwarzkopf was in Saudi Arabia last week with Defense Secretary Richard Cheney but since then had been directing the U.S. military response from the Florida base, with a deputy command center based in Saudi Arabia. But he said the main HQ would soon be set up in Saudi Arabia and that he personally was going.
EDITORS: John King is part of the national media pool accompanying U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: N.C. Businessman Recounts Dash to Freedom
With Iraq-Foreigners, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Businessman John Norman rode a taxi for five hours across the Iraqi desert in a harrowing flight to freedom, chain-smoking cigarettes and nibbling on hard-boiled eggs as the cab bounced toward Jordan. At the border checkpoint, Norman said, he feared for his life when Iraqi soldiers began firing their automatic weapons after a broadcast speech by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``It was an escape,'' Norman told The Charlotte Observer in a telephone interview Saturday. ``It wasn't a walk through. I didn't know whether I was going to leave Iraq alive.'' Norman, 38, was swept up into the U.S.-Iraqi military confrontation while working in Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, as a consultant to an Iraqi state bank. He returned to North Carolina on Friday, ending an odyssey that in three days took him by cab, private car and jumbo jet from Baghdad to Amman, Jordan, to London to Raleigh. A resident of the Raleigh area, Norman was on a 10-month assignment in Iraq for the accounting firm Ernst & Young. He was scheduled to leave on a month-long vacation Aug. 2, the day Iraq invaded Kuwait and the Baghdad airport was closed, stranding Norman and other foreigners. Norman, who stayed at the Sheraton Hotel, said he felt no immediate threat. But over the Aug. 4-5 weekend, he and his colleagues sensed a rapid deterioration in their situation as the United States turned up the heat on Iraq. Last Tuesday night, he said, the U.S. Embassy told them to leave Iraq as soon as possible. But no one was sure whether the borders were open. Although Norman and the others had planned to make a run for it Thursday, they quickly decided to leave Wednesday. After breakfast, Norman hit the streets looking for taxis that appeared durable enough to make the 300-mile trip to Jordan. He found three Iraqi brothers, taxi owners, who agreed to take five Americans and two Britons to Jordan in three cabs and a pickup truck at a cost of $1,000 per vehicle. They didn't know whether they could pass through the Iraqi frontier. ``We knew some of our compatriots had tried it,'' Norman said. ``They were not back yet. That was a positive indication they had gotten through.'' The group left Baghdad at 12:30 p.m. for a hot, stomach-knotting ride. Norman remembered the dash through the desert as the worst part of the journey. ``The anxiety of getting to the Iraqi border _ what would I do next,'' he said. They arrived at the border checkpoint at 5:30 p.m., only to go through repeated searches and passport checks. At one point, boisterous Iraqi soldiers unnerved the Americans when they fired their weapons into the air at the end of a speech by Hussein. ``It was more like celebration stuff,'' said colleague Pat Schenning, 47, of Alexandria, Va. ``We were just a little scared at that point.'' After four hours of hassles, the border guards cleared the Americans. About that time, employees from a U.S. bank arrived in cars and took them to Amman, where they arrived about 3:30 a.m., 15 hours after they had left Baghdad. ``They closed the border shortly after we left,'' Norman said. ``I think we were the last people out.''

DOC.HEAD: Hare Krishnas Dance Through Moscow's Gorky Park
DOC.TEXT: About three dozen Hare Krishnas danced and sang their way through Gorky Park on Sunday, but their advice to live simply in a material world lost something in the translation in material-less Moscow. The first legal Krishna celebration in the Soviet capital followed years of official harassment or persecution of devotees. ``You don't need meat to be healthy,'' Indra Dyvmna Swami of San Francisco told a group of curious Soviets gathered around a wooden cart carrying a colorful tent and a brightly painted statue of the Krishna god Jaganatha. Red carnations and daisies were strung together around the cart. The crowd of about 100 listened closely, but there likely would have been more enthusiasm _ and a longer line _ had the cart been selling meat. And when he told them: ``This material world has very little to offer,'' they nodded in agreement, knowing too well the expanses of barren shelves in Moscow stores. They also enviously eyed his Nike running shoes _ a hot item on the Moscow black market. Although Dyvmna and other group leaders were foreigners, most of the Krishnas were Soviet citizens. The noisy procession through the park interrupted an outdoor puppet show when the audience became more interested in the Krishnas. The puppet, apparently peeved, began mimicking their singing. As the Krishnas passed alongside the Moscow River, curious tour boat passengers craned to see what all the fuss was about. One of the new advertisements cropping up in Moscow was emblazoned on the side of the boat, touting Pepsi. Parents hoisted children onto their shoulders to get a better view of the spectacle of Krishnas, draped in their characteristic robes, twirling, clapping and singing in the path of their cart. People in foot-powered boats backpedaled and drifted to keep an eye on things. Dyvmna Swami stopped to autograph Krishna books. There were a few rough spots along the way as Krishnas pulling parallel ropes dragged their creaking cart on a circuitous route through the wooded park. Several times they had to lower the tent on the cart or take a detour because trees and power lines kept snagging its flag. Dyvmna Swami lost his translator at one point and briefly had to abandon proselytizing for more chanting. Later, after a Krishna trio belted out a rock version of a Krishna chant, he tried to resume his sermon to Soviets seated on wooden benches in an outdoor theater. But the sound system failed. Some Soviets walked out when the music ended. Others sat patiently, waiting for the equipment to be repaired and for the speeches to begin. Dyvmna Swami seemed pleased with the turnout and said that _ glitches notwithstanding _ it was a day to remember. ``This is the first year it's legal,'' he said. ``That's quite historic, actually, considering the history of the Soviet Union.'' Religion of all types was severely restricted until recently, and providing children with a religious education was a criminal offense. An unofficial demonstration took place last year, but this year, the Krishnas received permission for the public ceremony.

DOC.HEAD: Killing of Trafficker Represents Major Blow to Cartel
DOC.TEXT: A drug cartel leader killed by police was responsible for coordinating terrorist attacks in Colombia and shipments of cocaine to the United States, police said Sunday. Gustavo de Jesus Gaviria, the 41-year-old cousin of the Medellin cartel's leader, Pablo Escobar, was fatally shot Saturday in a shootout with anti-narcotics police raiding his apartment in southern Medellin, according to an official police statement. Gen. Octavio Vargas, the operations chief of the national police, said Escobar delegated Gaviria to manage the cartel's terrorist bombings and assasinations and its shipments of tons of cocaine to the United States and Europe. ``The damage caused to the cartel by the elimination of Gaviria is incalculable,'' Vargas said in a telephone interview. Vargas, who planned Saturday's raid, said Medellin residents angered by the cartel's attacks had tipped police off to Gaviria's whereabouts two weeks ago. In the last year the cartel carried out nearly 300 bombings that left 301 people dead. Early this year, the traffickers' began gunning down Medellin police, killing 178 of them before the cartel declared a unilateral truce last month. The truce is apparently intended to convince President Cesar Gaviria, inaugurated Tuesday, to abandon the government's crackdown on traffickers. President Gaviria is not related to Gustavo Gaviria. Vargas said police had taken special care to study the layout of Gustavo Gaviria's luxury apartment, equipped with bullet-resistant windows and a closed-circuit television monitoring system. Gaviria, wanted in both France and the United States on cocaine trafficking charges, battled police with his Uzi submachine gun and an M-14 automatic rifle, Vargas said. Witnesses quoted by newspapers said the gunbattle between Gaviria and police lasted about 15 minutes. Police also captured one of Gaviria's associates, Alexandra Tapias, in the raid, Vargas said. The police statement said that another woman was also detained. She was not identified. Vargas said Gaviria's sister had claimed the suspect's body, which was to be buried in a Medellin cemetary. In the last eight months, authorities have killed two other cartel leaders in gunbattles. Police killed Jose Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha in December and John Jairo Arias earlier this year. Medellin police remain on alert, fearing that the killing may prompt the cartel to carry out retaliatory attacks, the police statement said. Gaviria's name first entered police records in 1976, when he was arrested along with Escobar and charged with transporting 40 pounds of cocaine in a car tire. A judge subsequently freed the two men without explanation. Four years later the suspects were considered two of the richest, most powerful drug barons in the country. In 1987, authorities accused Gaviria of responsibility for the assassinations of two Colombian intellegence police officers. A judge found him innocent, citing a lack of evidence. Last year, a French court convicted Gaviria of smuggling nearly 1,000 pounds of cocaine into the country and sentenced him in his absence to 20 years in prison. The United States has requested Gaviria's extradition on charges of cocaine distribution and money laundering. In recent years, Florida authorities have confiscated two of Gaviria's luxury apartments in Dade County and Miami Beach, according to a report in Bogota's El Espectador newspaper. The Medellin cartel and a rival group in the city of Cali are responsible for processing and smuggling 80 percent of the cocaine sold in the United States, U.S. authorities have said. Police have called Gaviria the third most important member of the Medellin cartel, led by Escobar and another trafficking suspect, Jorge Luis Ochoa.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Plane Makes Emergency Landing
DOC.TEXT: A Continental Airlines jet with 157 people aboard made an emergency landing shortly after takeoff Sunday morning when one of its three engines caught fire, officials said. The Boeing 727, bound for Denver, landed safely shortly after 9 a.m., said Leo Roeske, air traffic manager at Gallatin Field, about 70 miles southeast of Helena in central Montana. David Messing, a spokesman for Continental in Houston, said the passengers left the plane by sliding down emergency chutes, Messing said. No one was injured. Roeske said he didn't know whether the fire was the cause of engine failure or the result of it. Firefighters put firefighting foam on the engine after the plane landed. The cause of problem would not be known until the engine could be dismantled and examined, Messing said. He added that the plane normally flies on two of its three engines.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Ties Withdrawal to Surrender of Israeli-Occupied Territories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf to include comment from White House. Pickup 10th pvs, `Saddam's proposal...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TLV1,DHA1,WX7,LaserColor WX107
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein, under international quarantine for his invasion of Kuwait, said Sunday that one of his conditions for resolving the Persian Gulf crisis is Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories. He said ``many will be burned'' if war breaks out. The Iraqi president demanded the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Saudi Arabia and the end to U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq, which forced him to ask his people to be thrifty with meat and clothing. At the same time, the United States announced it will intercept Iraqi oil shipments to tighten the squeeze on Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. American and Arab soldiers have been massing to defend Saudi Arabia from Iraqi expansionism. A group of Iraqi pilots offered to fly suicide missions against U.S. ships in the Persian Gulf. Britain, France and other countries have joined U.S. warships in the Middle East in an attempt to deter a possible Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia. In a televised statement read by a spokesman, Saddam suggested he would tie any Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. Israel took the territories from Egypt and Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. ``If America and its allies will not accept this initiative, we will resist by force,'' Saddam said. ``They will leave this country with their tails behind them.'' He also warned: ``If the spark of war is started, many will be burned.'' Israel dismissed Saddam's proposal as ``cheap propaganda.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the United States ``categorically rejects'' Saddam's proposals and said it backs the U.N. Security Council's call ``for the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.'' ``These latest conditions and threats are another attempt at distracting from Iraq's isolation and at imposing a new status quo,'' Fitzwater said. Saddam's proposal appeared to be aimed at broadening the debate over his invasion of Kuwait into a discussion of a host of Middle East problems, some of which remain unresolved after decades of talks and war. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. Central Command, told pool reporters that deployment of troops is running ahead of schedule and U.S. soldiers are aware of possible terrorist attacks against them in the Middle East. He also said of the Iraqis: ``If they do make an attack they are going to pay a price for it.'' A U.S. airman died Sunday in Saudi Arabia as the result of an accident, becoming the first American killed in the desert operation, the Pentagon said. The dead man was identified as Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campsi. The Pentagon said the accident is being investigated but had no further details. There were signs the Iraqis are girding for a long siege. One day after warning that black marketeers in Iraq would be executed, Saddam urged Iraqi women to cut meat consumption in half and be frugal with clothing. ``What is demanded is that no one stockpile food supplies,'' Saddam said. ``Stockpiles will bring about shortages.'' A U.N. embargo on trade has choked off incoming shipments of food, military parts and essential goods. However, the embargo may allow humanitarian shipments of food. Iraq's oil exports have virtually trickled shut. But Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States would honor a request by the Kuwaiti government in exile to intercept Iraqi oil shipments. ``Let's not use the word blockade,'' Baker said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' ``Let's just say we have the legal basis for interdicting these things.'' U.S. and allied warships are poised to meet Iraqi tankers coming from the Persian Gulf, Red Sea or Mediterranean Sea. Iraq is dependent on oil exports to buy food and supplies for its 17 million people. Iraq is virtually encircled on the ground with the possible exception of Jordan. Turkish Premier Yildirim Akbulut said Sunday he will ask Parliament for the power to declare a state of war and send armed forces into combat if the crisis worsens. He called it a precautionary move. To the south, 10,000 Egyptian and Moroccan troops are joining 50,000 U.S. soldiers moving into Saudi Arabia. Syria, on Iraq's northwestern border, has also pledged troops. To the east, Iraq is still in a state of war with Iran although a U.N.-sponsored cease-fire has been holding since 1988. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani called the takeover of Kuwait ``one of Iraq's more abominable acts'' but he also said the U.S. intervention was illegal. ``The presence of foreign forces has inflamed the Persian Gulf and the region has become like a powder keg,'' Rafsanjani said Sunday. In the Jordan city of Mafraq, thousands of people converged for an anti-American rally organized by the Jordanian Committee in Support of Iraq. The rallies began after Saddam's call for a ``holy war'' against Saudi Arabia and Western countries intervening in the Persian Gulf. Police stopped about 50 pro-Iraqi protesters marching on the U.S. Embassy in the capital city of Amman, dispersing them peacefully, a witness said. An estimated 10,000 Palestinians staged a noisy demonstration of support for Iraq at a refugee camp in southern Lebanon. Chanting ``Death to America!'' the demonstrators hanged effigies of President Bush, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Saudi Arabian King Fahd. A PLO official said 500 refugees at another camp had volunteered to go to Iraq to fight against an American attack. But in Bangladesh, hundreds of people demonstrated outside Iraq's embassy to secure the safety of 110,000 Bangladesh citizens trapped in the invasion. Demonstrators shouted ``Iraqi troops get out of Kuwait!'' In Israel, stores reported panic purchases of gas masks following Iraqi threats to attack with chemical weapons. A British citizen was reportedly shot in Kuwait near the Saudi border, and scores of foreigners were returning to their homelands Sunday with stories of rapes and killings by Iraqi soldiers. Britain's Foreign Office said Sunday it could not determine immediately whether the reported shooting on Saturday night was fatal. Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said the report came from unidentified people who had crossed the border recently. Penelope Nabokov, the 10-year-old California girl who was detoured by the blitzkrieg on her way to visit her mother, fled to freedom Saturday and was on her way to meet her parents Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: defense policies.
The Washington Post
DOC.TEXT: It is heartening to see Egypt exercising leadership in the strategy to force Iraq out of Kuwait. For the United States and Europe, the primary interest in political stability there is the flow of oil. Iraq's neighbors have much more at stake. Iraq has made it clear that its intentions go beyond this month's conquest. It proposes to make itself dominant among the Arabs. Saddam Hussein has been claiming, in recent days, to speak for all the Arab world in a great test of will and of strength with the Americans. But most of the Arab world denounced him on Friday in the Arab League's meeting, and now Egyptian forces as well as Americans face him at the Saudi border.
DOC.HEAD: The Detroit News
DOC.TEXT: No one in Washington, it seems, wants to use the ``H'' word _ hostages _ to describe the several thousand Americans who were caught in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the latter's blitzkrieg conquest of the former two weeks ago. With every day that passes without their being allowed to leave, however, it becomes harder to avoid the conclusion that they are being held against their will. (President Bush) should set a deadline for the unconditional release of the Americans. Failure to comply will result in attacks on Iraqi oil fields and other targets. Harm to any Americans would be considered an act of all-out war.
DOC.HEAD: The Philadelphia Inquirer
DOC.TEXT: An Arab force on the Saudi border will signal that an attack will embroil him (Hussein) in an inter-Arab war. It is hoped that this would also undercut his attempt to portray himself as the hero who would save Arab oil fields and Muslim holy places from unclean Western hands. ... The real test of global cooperation against Iraq will be if that blockade holds. It could take months for sanctions to move Baghdad, and Saddam Hussein will undoubtedly counterattack. He may use hostages or terrorism, or undermine Arab leaders who stand up to him. It will take patience, and test White House leadership, to keep a global blockade going. But the best inspiration to stick together may come from listening to the words of Saddam Hussein.
DOC.HEAD: Los Angeles Times
DOC.TEXT: The crisis provoked by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has escalated into the first major confrontation of the post-Cold War era and new realities, both hopeful and sobering, are emerging. Foremost among the latter is the realization that a world liberated from the threat of nuclear annihilation will not be free of mortal danger. As the case of Saddam Hussein makes all too clear, there remain good old-fashioned nationalist dictators every bit as aggressive and threatening as Stalinist ideologues. ... But ... much that has transpired so far should be a source of hope. The willingness of the vast majority of the world's nations to directly and collectively engage Hussein's challenge is, as foreign policy analyst Stanley Hoffman put it, ``quite remarkable.'' In fact, if the anti-Hussein coalition holds together, this crisis could, as former diplomat Richard N. Gardner has said, ``constitute a landmark event in the history of this century.''

DOC.HEAD: DC Residents Don't Want Jail Time Or New Trial For Mayor
With AM-Barry Future
DOC.TEXT: Most Washington residents don't want Mayor Marion Barry to go to jail, but they don't believe either that he should be retried on any of 12 unresolved federal charges against him, poll results published Sunday show. A majority of respondents to The Washington Post poll said also that they do not want Barry to seek another term as mayor or to run for a city council post. Better than half of those asked said they believed Barry should resign from office immediately. A U.S. District Court jury on Friday convicted Barry of one cocaine possession charge and acquitted him on another. The panel was unable to reach a verdict on the 12 remaining counts and U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson declared a mistrial. The survey of 603 randomly selected residents of the nation's capital was conducted Saturday for the Post by Chilton Research of Radnor, Pa. The newspaper did not indicate a margin of error, but said that because of ``the practical difficulties associated with doing a public opinion poll in one day,'' the survey results ``should be interpreted with caution.'' Sixty-four percent of the respondents said Barry should not go to jail, while 31 percent said he should serve time. The remaining 5 percent either had no opinion or refused to respond. Seventy-three percent of the respondents said Barry should not be tried again. Twenty-three percent favored a new court case and 4 percent either had no opinion or refused to respond. Barry has hinted to associates recently that he would not run for mayor, but might attempt a return to the city council, where he served for four years before ascending to the city's top office. It is too late for him to file as a candidate for the Democratic nomination in the Sept. 11, primary although he could still run as an independent in the Nov. 6 general election. But 63 percent of the respondents said they would not vote for Barry. Thirty-two percent said they would, while 5 percent either had no opinion or did not respond. Fifty-two percent said Barry should resign immediately, while 45 percent wanted him to remain in office. Three percent either had to opinion or refused to respond.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Weapons Kill And Maim, But Effective Treatment Available
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 6th graf, ``Both chemical ...'' to CORRECT spelling of `ordnance' and fix typo in `vaporize.' ^By PAUL RECER
DOC.TEXT: For the first time since World War I, American troops stare across a no-man's land at a potential enemy who has used chemical weapons and may do so again. Iraq is known to have stockpiled at least two chemical weapons. One burns the skin like liquid fire. The other kills in minutes by disrupting nervous system functions. And Iraq's army, massed along a border across from U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, is known to have used at least one of the chemicals in its war with Iran and against Kurdish dissident groups in its own country. Iraq's burning chemical is thought to be the same mustard gas that confronted the great-grandfathers of today's U.S. troops in the trenches of World War I Europe. It worked so well 70 years ago that civilized nations banned the use of such weapons. Mustard gas still does its work with ghastly efficiency. The other chemical agent, commonly called nerve gas, is a group of compounds added to the arsenals of war by advances in chemistry and in biological understanding. It takes but a drop of concentrated nerve agent, absorbed by the skin, to kill. Both chemical weapons can be delivered by bomb, artillery shell or mine. When the ordnance explodes, the chemicals vaporize, spreading quickly. Mustard, in a gas or droplet form, is readily absorbed by exposed skin and is quickly taken up by inner layers of tissue. ``Initially, there are no symptoms,'' says Lloyd Roberts, a research administrator at the Army's Institute of Chemical Defense. ``There is a delayed effect.'' Reactions vary depending on concentrations and individuals, said Roberts, but generally within one to six hours a victim will experience itching and reddening of the skin. Within 12 hours, huge blisters appear. The blisters burst and the skin is sloughed, leaving large, gaping wounds ripe for infection. It is very much like a third degree burn, said Roberts, ``and that's how we treat it.'' Dead skin must be pulled away and the wound washed with sterile solution. Healing is slow and painful. Infection a constant threat. ``The eyes are the most vulnerable to mustard,'' said Roberts. Even a medium exposure causes pain and swelling and the white of the eye turns an angry red. In heavy exposures, there are severe lacerations of the cornea. Some soldiers in World War I were blinded. But mustard does its worst damage in the respiratory system. ``It tends to be lethal only when inhaled,'' Roberts said. Just as it blisters the skin, inhaled mustard gas blisters the lungs and the airway of the respiratory tract. Breathing becomes tortured. Patients cough blood. Internal surface tissue dies and pneumonia becomes a fearful threat. Medical care depends on the symptoms. A mild dose, said Roberts, causes hoarseness and sore throat and no treatment is required. For a cough, the Army uses syrups. For laryngitis, there is sterile steam and bed rest. For severe cases, patients are hospitalized for months and treated aggressively with antibiotics to ward off pneumonia. ``Mortality from mustard gas in World War I was about one percent,'' said Roberts. Now, with modern care, it could be even less. Unlike mustard, that can cause large obvious wounds, nerve agents are sly, quick killers, attacking the body at the molecular level. Readily absorbed by the skin, nerve gas goes to work immediately. It kills by disrupting a chemical reaction that occurs each time a muscle moves. Roberts said nerve agents bind to a protein molecule called acetyclcholinesterase, of AChE, and keep it from doing its job. AChE normally destroys another protein molecule called acetylcholine, or ACh. This molecule is a neurotransmitter that moves from nerve to muscle each time a voluntary muscle operates. It also works in the brain to carry signals from cell to cell. Normally, when the neurotransmitter has done its job, it is immediately inactivated by AChE. But if the nerve gas keeps the AChE from working, then the neurotransmitter builds up and continues to act on the muscles and brain cells. Muscle control is lost. Spasms set in as muscles contract, time after time. There's weakness and collapse. Respiration is depressed. Heart beat slows. Convulsions. Unconsciousness. The diaphragm muscle stops working. Death. ``The person suffocates,'' said Roberts. ``Unprotected, a person is dead within 10 minutes, tops.'' As with any chemical weapon, the effects depend on the concentration. After a weak exposure, symptoms can be mild and pass within hours. A stronger, non-lethal concentration may cause symptoms that last a day or longer. But there are seldom long-term effects, said Roberts. ``With a nerve agent, if you survive, you can return to duty within a week,'' he said. ``It either kills you or you recover.'' One way to modify or even completely block the nerve gas effect is with a chemical antidote. And Roberts said American troops are issued two of these. One is atropine and the other is called pralidoxime choride. The drugs are carried in spring-loaded syringes. At the first sign of exposure, a soldier can slap the syringe against a thigh and the drugs quickly enter the body. Both atropine and pralidoxime choride, said Roberts, work by inhibiting the excess ACh neurotransmitter molecule. In effect, the drugs for a brief time do the job of the acetylcholinesterase that was attacked by the nerve gas. The first line of defense against a chemical attack, though, are protective garments: boots, rubber gloves, masks and hooded helmets. On the battlefield of chemical warfare, survival means every inch of skin must be covered and every breath filtered _ even in an Arabian desert where midday temperatures may soar to 110 degrees.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Links Withdrawal to Israeli Surrender of Occupied Territories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to bring quotes into line with AP translation. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein on Sunday declared readiness to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis _ if Israel withdraws from occupied Arab territories, Syria pulls out of Lebanon and U.S. forces leave Saudi Arabia. The Iraqi president also demanded an end to international economic action against his nation. In a statement read by an announcer on Baghdad radio and television, Saddam said foreign powers intervening in the region were setting off ``the spark of war'' which would ``burn many.'' The statement was translated by The Associated Press. If the international community wanted foreign forces kept in the region, he said, they should be replaced by Arab troops ``with the (U.N.) Security Council making all the arrangements'' on which nationalities should be involved. Saddam said if the United States and its allies did not not accept his initiative, Iraq would ``resist its evil intentions and aggressive schemes.'' ``We will be victorious, with God's help,'' he said. ``The evil-doers will regret their acts when they are driven out in shame from the region.'' He said any Arab force should not include Egypt, which he said was being used by the United States as a launching pad for ``conspiracies against the Arabs.'' Egypt and Morocco were the first Arab countries to send troops to Saudi Arabia to face Iraqi forces massed along that country's border with Kuwait. The Arab deployment came after the United States and other nations sent ships, planes and thousands of troops to the region to defend strategic, oil-rich Saudi Arabia. In his statement, Saddam called for ``all cases of occupation, and those cases that have been portrayed as occupation'' to be be resolved simultaneously, under the ``same principles and guidelines.'' He linked any withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, a Syrian pullout from Lebanon, and the resolution of Iran-Iraq land disputes stemming from their 1980-88 war. All of those conflicts have remained intractable in the face of negotiations, sometimes over a period of years, or outright warfare. By bringing them up now, Saddam could be seeking to buy time, broaden the argument over his conquest of Kuwait, and attract Arab support by calling for the surrender of the Israeli-occupied lands. Israel dismissed Saddam's call as ``cheap propaganda.'' There was no immediate reaction from Syria, which was unlikely for strategic reasons to comply with the demand that it leave Lebanon. Some Arabs have criticized the United States and others for sending troops in response to the takeover of Kuwait but not taking similar action to end Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which it captured in the 1967 Middle East war. In his statement, Saddam demanded an end to international economic sanctions, calling on all nations to freeze immediately all ``boycott and siege decisions'' against Iraq. But even as the Iraqi leader made the demand, the United States was pledging to tighten the economic noose. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Sunday on ABC that the United States would intercept Iraqi oil shipments. He said the move was in response to the exiled Kuwaiti government's call for world governments to enforce United Nations sanctions against Iraq. The U.N. Security Council approved a worldwide trade embargo on Iraq and Kuwait on Aug. 6. The Iraqi president reiterated Baghdad's longstanding claims on Kuwait, which it annexed Aug. 8. When Kuwait, a former British colony, became independent nearly three decades ago, Iraq refused then to recognize its sovreignty. ``Iraq has never recognized the crime committed by the colonialists,'' Saddam said. Earlier Sunday, in a statement also read on Baghdad radio and television, Saddam urged the Iraqi people to prepare for hardships that may result from the international economic sanctions. Also Sunday, the Iraqi News Agency said a group of pilots has offered to fly suicide missions against U.S. ships sent to the gulf as part of the multinational force being deployed to defend Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Two Iraqi Pilots Said to Defect to Saudi Arabia
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two Iraqi air force pilots have defected by flying their MiG warplanes to a base in northern Saudi Arabia, diplomatic sources in the Middle East said Sunday. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Soviet-built warplanes landed Saturday at the Hafr al-Baten base, the main center for the foreign troop buildup in Saudi Arabia. The U.S. State Department said it had not heard the report. The Kuwaiti Embassy in Washington said it had heard the report but could not confirm it. U.S. and other foreign countries are sending forces to Saudi Arabia to defend against any attack by Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The diplomatic sources said the planes were MiGs, but they did not know the precise type. The pilots were not identified, and there were no other immediate details. Iraq has at least 70 MiG-23 ground attack fighters, as well as 70 MiG-21 and 18 MiG-29 fighters. It also has eight MiG-25 reconnaissance planes and a variety of MiG training planes.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Protest in Support of Iraq
With Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 Palestinians demonstrated Sunday in a refugee camp in southern Lebanon in support of Iraq. A PLO official said 500 youths volunteered to fight with Iraq against a possible American attack. Another pro-Iraqi demonstration was reported in Jordan. In Bangladesh, hundreds rallied against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The demonstrators at Lebanon's Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp chanted ``Death to America!'' and called Saudi Arabia's King Fahd an ``American spy.'' They also hanged effigies of President Bush, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Fahd. Some of the demonstrators marched carrying pictures of Saddam and Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat. At the end of the protest, a PLO official told the crowd that 500 Palestinians from Ein el-Hilweh, the largest refugee camp in Lebanon, had volunteered to go to Iraq to fight against a potential American attack. But also Sunday, Hussein Musawi, the head of a pro-Syrian wing of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God criticized Palestinians for supporting Saddam, whom he referred to as ``a Satan.'' Hezbollah is Iran's main ally in Lebanon and an umbrella for several hostage-holding factions. ``Saddam is a Satan, not a Moslem leader,'' Musawi said. ``The one who waged war against the Islamic republic (Iran) and Syria and who unleashed chemical weapons against the Kurds is not a hero but a Satan.'' In Jordan on Sunday, police stopped about 50 pro-Iraqi protesters from marching on the U.S. Embassy, a witness said. In the northern city of Mafraq, 50 miles north of the capital, thousands of people converged for a protest rally organised by the Jordanian Committee in Support of Iraq. A large percentage of Jordan's population is Palestinian. The small crowd in Amman chanted pro-Iraqi and anti-American slogans and banging their fists on parked cars. Scores of policemen stopped the protesters at a traffic circle about 100 yards from the embassy and they dispersed without incident, said the witness, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Minor demonstrations have been staged for most of the week in Jordan, giving vent to a growing wave of anti-Americanism following the dispatch of U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia to protect the oil-rich kingdom against possible Iraqi attack. In Bangladesh, hundreds of people shouting ``Iraqi troops get out of Kuwait!'' rallied outside the Iraqi Embassy to secure the safety of 110,000 Bangladesh citizens trapped in the invasion. The demonstrators dispersed after they were allowed to hand over a protest letter to the Iraqi ambassador.

DOC.HEAD: Villagers Say Soldiers Kill At Least 25 Villagers, Rape Women
DOC.TEXT: Government troops killed 25 people in a raid on two villages in the Kashmir valley in search of Moslem separatists who had ambushed an army convoy, residents said Sunday. Villagers said at least 50 people were missing, at least 15 women were raped by the soldiers and many people were beaten during Friday's raids. The government said 24 militants were killed by the troops in the area, but said they were slain in a shootout. It denied the accusations of rape. The Times of India newspaper put the number of dead at 45. The army raid followed an ambush on a troop convoy near the Pazipora and Balipora villages, about 58 miles northwest of Srinagar, residents said. Reinforcements poured into the villages in search of the attackers, they said. Ghulam Mohammed Butt, one of the villagers, said the troops shot and killed his two teen-age sons, Farooq and Bashir Ahmed. ``We told them we didn't know about the militants, but they didn't listen,'' he said. Other villagers said 15 women who had barricaded themselves in a house, were raped. At least 50 men who had fled into surrounding paddy fields and pine forests were missing and feared killed, they said. Girish Saxena, the governor of Jammu-Kashmir state, said troops killed 24 militants after they came under fire. He said he had not heard any accusations of rape and that he would order an official inquiry if the reports were true. Security forces in Kashmir often are accused of excesses in containing the Moslem movement for secession of the valley from Hindu-majority India. At least 985 people have been killed in Kashmir since Jan 20, when the government launched a crackdown on the insurrection. The valley is predominantly Moslem and is part of Jammu-Kashmir state, the only one of India's 25 provinces with a Moslem majority. At least 65 percent of the state's 6 million people are Moslem. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people, while Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Barry's Latest Political Move May Be Abandonment Of Party Affiliation
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 5th graf, ``Winning a council xxx to include that Barry elected to city council in 1974
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry is receiving conflicting advice on whether he should run for city council, but is planning nonetheless to drop his Democratic party affiliation as a first step, aides said Sunday. Barry, convicted Friday of one cocaine possession charge and acquitted of another, plans to drop out of the Democratic Party and register as an independent on Monday, said top Barry aides who spoke only on condition of anonymity. That would be Barry's first step toward reviving his political career with a campaign for an at-large seat on the District of Columbia's 13-member council, the aides said. Monday is the deadline for switching parties. If Barry becomes an independent, he would then have to gather the signatures of 2,000 registered city voters before his name could be placed on the ballot. He would compete for two city-wide council seats with winners of the Republican, Democrat, and Statehood party primaries. Winning a council seat would allow Barry to maximize his future city pension earnings and let him stay active in local politics, which he has dominated since he was first elected mayor in 1978. He had been elected to the city council in 1974. ``His life is politics, and he doesn't know anything else,'' one Barry adviser said. ``If he stays clean, he can contribute a lot. That's what he wants to do.'' Barry announced in June that he would not seek a fourth term as mayor. He has 16 years of city government service and would be eligible for a full pension after 20 years. But Barry's supporters are deeply divided over whether the mayor should remain in politics, other sources said. While some believe Barry has been exonerated and should resume his political career, others are wary of antagonizing U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson or prosecutors. ``There are some, including his top government aides, who believe he should do nothing to irritate either Jackson or (U.S. Attorney Jay B.) Stephens, said one associate. ``The feeling is, `Don't do anything to draw attention to yourself.''' Jackson has not yet set a sentencing date for Barry's misdemeanor cocaine possession conviction, which carries a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. In addition, Stephens has not yet revealed whether he intends to retry Barry on a dozen charges against the mayor on which the jury couldn't reach a verdict. Some of Barry's advisers believe the government would be more likely to pursue the case _ and Jackson would be more inclined to send the mayor to jail _ if Barry is actively campaigning for office. Stephens has said only that the trial evidence will be reviewed before he decides whether to pursue the matter, but politics have been intertwined with the case since Barry's Jan. 18 arrest in an FBI sting operation. During plea bargain negotiations, the mayor has said, Stephens insisted that Barry would have to resign his office as part of any agreement with the government. Law enforcement sources have corroborated Barry's account of the negotiations. And there are other, more tangible, indications that a Barry candidacy might not be in the mayor's best interests. A Washington Post poll published Sunday shows that while a majority of those interviewed believe the government should abandon is prosecution of the mayor, a greater percentage believe Barry himself should scuttle any plans to run for office this year. In addition, other sources said that Barry's wife Effi is deeply opposed to the mayor running for office. ``She has been referring to politics as a thing of the past,'' said one Barry associate. ``She has said, in so many words, that she is not interested in another campaign.'' ``In the end, he will do what he wants to do _ just like he always has,'' said one longtime Barry associate. ``Making the party switch will allow him to keep his options open, to test the water a little while longer.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Rejects Saddam's Offer for Withdrawal
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Palestinian leader, foreign ministry, Arens. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `The Cabinet...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TLV1
DOC.TEXT: Israel on Sunday rejected as ``cheap propaganda'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's proposal linking a possible Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli pullout from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. But Palestinian leaders on Sunday welcomed Saddam's proposal, saying it would boost their demands for a homeland. ``If the Americans will take the initiative seriously, then we can get something good from a bad situation,'' said Faisal Husseini, the leading pro-PLO activist in the occupied territories. Also Sunday, the Israeli military refused comment on foreign reports that Israel placed its air force on alert and moved anti-aircraft missiles to the Jordanian border following threats from Iraq to use chemical weapons. Israeli stores, meanwhile, reported a huge increase in the purchases of gas masks. The Iraqi proposal was Saddam's third attempt in five days to involve Israel in the Persian Gulf crisis to try to win grass-roots support in Arab countries. In his statement, 11 days after his conquest of Kuwait, Saddam suggested he would tie any Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and a Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. Syria maintains 40,000 troops in Lebanon. ``I suggest that all cases of occupation _ or cases that are described as occupation _ be resolved at the same time,'' Saddam said in a statement read on Baghdad television by an announcer. ``Saddam Hussein is trying through all kinds of exercises to do away with the international force which is confronting him, and to evade the economic sanctions which are being enforced against him,'' Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's adviser Avi Pazner said in a statement. ``His so-called initiative is nothing but cheap propaganda.'' Saddam's idea was a ``propaganda ploy to divert world opinion from the main issue: a large country devouring a small neighbor in naked, unprovoked aggression,'' said Foreign Ministry spokesman Yosef Amihud. Defense Minister Moshe Arens, speaking to foreign reporters in Tel Aviv before Saddam's demands were made public, said ``there is no correlation at all between whatever success or lack of success we may have in dealing with the Palestinian problem and Saddam Hussein.'' The Cabinet met Sunday followed British reports that Israel has placed its air force on alert and a report by the NBC network that American-made HAWK anti-aircraft missiles have been moved to the Jordanian border. The military refused to comment on the reports. The missile deployment could be linked to media reports quoting Defense Ministry aide Dan Naveh as saying Iraq had no missiles armed with chemical warheads and other informed sources as saying that only the Iraqi air force could strike Israel. In Israel, anxiety mounted. In ultra-Orthodox neighborhoods, wall posters spoke of a ``state of war with Iraq'' and called on ``all the boys and girls, youths and yeshiva students to cancel all vacations... and return to classes to study Torah and pray.'' Stores reported a record increase in the purchases of gas masks and other protective gear. ``We have sold hundreds of gas masks since the gulf crisis. A week ago we would only sell a few per week,'' said Ilan Shalev, sales manager at Tel Aviv's Gazit safety equipment store. An army spokesman said there was no need to begin a mass distribution of gas masks. The spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there were enough masks ``for all citizens of Israel,'' including Israeli Arabs, as well as tourists. There are about 810,000 Israeli Arabs. A former Civil Guard commander, Aryeh Biro, said there were no masks for the 1.7 million Palestinians living in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. ``For residents of the territories, unlike the Israeli Arabs, we think we have no masks for them,'' Biro said on Israel army radio. ``We don't need to give them masks because we don't expect danger in these areas.''

DOC.HEAD: Cowboy Fake Wanted in Indiana, Texas Arrested in Missouri
DOC.TEXT: Police say a mysterious cowboy with a black hat and missing fingertips has been brought to justice in Missouri after leading a band that rustled horses and stole high-priced saddles from New York to Texas. ``Horse stealing and saddle theft are crimes that most people think died with the Old West. But it is still really big business,'' said Hendricks County sheriff's Lt. Stephen G. Golden, who had been tailing the man for months. The cowboy, who says his name is William Robert Stanley, was being held Sunday in lieu of $300,000 bond in a Springfield, Mo., jail on theft and other charges. Two accomplices also were arrested for theft and burglary. Indiana police say the real William Robert Stanley is dead, and the rustler made off with his name. Some of the man's fingertips have been either burned or filed off, making positive identification by fingerprints difficult _ the arrested man told police he lost the fingertips shoeing horses. The tall, slender, sandy-haired man is suspected of stealing more than 100 saddles and other gear during the past three years, Golden said. Police also have been trying to trace at least 13 horses that witnesses reported seeing in the cowboy's trailer in recent weeks. Some of the horses and gear were stolen in Oklahoma, Tennessee and Texas, that shipped north and sold in auction barns in Indiana and other states, authorities said. The real William Robert Stanley, 34, of Irving, Texas, died in Dallas on Jan. 18 of complications from the treatment of leukemia. He had been assistant administrator of a hospital in nearby Fort Worth. Golden believes the cowboy went to Stanley's hometown of Concord, N.H., after Stanley's death and obtained an official copy of his birth certificate. A driver's license in Stanley's name was issued Jan. 26 at Tulsa, Okla. About a week later, Stanley's widow, Ruthie Stanley, got a phone call from a man claiming to be from the local Social Security Administration office in Texas. The caller, who Golden believes was the cowboy, wanted to confirm Stanley's Social Security number. Mrs. Stanley said the caller ``was so sorry for my loss, and he said that I would get a packet of information from Social Security. I never got one.'' A duplicate Social Security card was issued April 11 in the Grand Prairie, Texas, Social Security office, Golden said. The card was issued even though government computers showed Stanley was dead and benefits were being paid to his family. ``My husband was really an honest person, and it breaks my heart to see his name drug through the mud,'' Mrs. Stanley said.

DOC.HEAD: Largest Motor Home Owner Travels the Fair Circuit
LaserPhoto CO1
DOC.TEXT: Joe Harrington is careful where he drives his motor home, because some cities just aren't big enough for the two of them. Harrington drives what he calls the ``world's largest, most unusual motor home,'' now on display at the Ohio State Fair. His house, dubbed ``Ninth Wonder,'' is 12{ feet high, 8 feet wide and 46 feet long. Harrington, 60, a former truck driver, spent 17,000 hours in 3{ years building the vehicle, made of parts from five different trucks. The motor home has several remarkable amenities, including an 8 x 16 foot porch that folds under the vehicle, seven stereos with 26 speakers, three refrigerators, three television sets and a central heating and air conditioning system. The home sleeps five. The Charlotte, N.C., resident said he is careful where he takes his mobile mansion. ``Chicago's got too many underpasses,'' said Harrington. ``I took a TV crew out in it one time and when the first bridge came up, they were all screaming for dear life.'' He said he sits up so high _ about 12 feet _ that he must constantly peer at his speedometer because it can feel like the home is barely moving. Its eight-cylinder, 325 horsepower engine allows ``Ninth Wonder'' to travel up to 100 mph _ at 10 miles to the gallon, Harrington said. ``Truckers beg me everywhere to pull over at the next stop so they can take a look at it,'' he said. Harrington, who travels to fairs three months out of the year, said he started hitting the fair circuit in 1988. This is his second trip to Ohio's fair, which runs through Aug. 19. Intrigued passersby can pay $1.00 for a tour. You can't miss Harrington. He'll be on his porch, grilling food and watching TV.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Stockpiled Munitions in Thailand, Newspaper Says
DOC.TEXT: Green Berets stationed in Southeast Asia illegally stockpiled millions of dollars worth of U.S. ammunition and explosives, and some of it may have ended up on Thailand's black market, a newspaper reported Sunday. The San Francisco Examiner also said former Army Special Forces officers tried to cover up the misuse of U.S. military hardware. The stockpiling of tons of bullets, grenades, mines and plastic explosives occurred as late as last year, the newspaper said, citing military documents and interviews with investigators and former members of the elite units. ``U.S. Army Special Operations lost control of millions of dollars of American arms and ammunition over five years,'' said Mike Bracy, a former sergeant with the Okinawa-based 1st Battalion, 1st Special Forces. In two months alone, 1 million dollars worth of ordnance ``dropped off the books,'' he said. Bracy and another former battalion sergeant, Bob Finley, claim they were subjected to harassment, psychiatric observation and death threats when they tried to alert superiors to the problems, the Examiner said. Finley retired. Bracy was honorably discharged last year after the office of U.S. Rep. Barbara Boxer, D-Calif., intervened. Boxer said the Pentagon inspector general's office told her two weeks ago its investigation confirmed that munitions intended for training use were winding up on the black market, and that the Special Forces were involved. The Special Forces, known as the Green Berets, are experts in unconventional warfare and considered key to extending American military power into foreign trouble spots. Special Forces units in Southeast Asia are involved in training soldiers from Thailand, the Philippines, Singapore, Korea, and Malaysia. The Army has denied any wrongdoing by the Special Forces. But an Army investigation cited by the Examiner said the 1st Battalion, 1st Special Forces _ specifically its 80-man Bravo Company operating in Thailand _ was ``torn by divisions, rumors and criminal activity.'' Battalion members are doing business on Bangkok's black market, and there are lax controls on the main Green Beret stockpile, the newspaper said, quoting unidentified military and civilian sources. Finley and other Bravo Company members said munitions were given to Thai units, contrary to strict requirements that only the Green Berets themselves use them. Lt. Col. Robert Suchke, commander of the 1st Battalion in 1988 and 1989, said during an interrogation that he didn't know what his soldiers stored in Thailand, the Examiner said. He also said he didn't know who controlled the stockpile or who had the key to the biggest cache, a bunker filled with munitions on a Royal Thai Army base, according to the paper. Bracy, originally assigned to an internal military investigation of the matter, claimed high-level officers in Southeast Asia either were involved in illicit activities or ``turned a blind eye.'' Finley and Bracy _ who collated all the munitions requisition forms, inventory lists and other documents _ said they took their evidence and complaints to U.S. military authorities in Japan. Bracy said he was ordered last August to immediately halt any criminal investigation and turn over information to higher-ups. Finley said he was ordered to burn records of Bravo Company Sgt. Maj. Edward Gleason, who started the stockpile in 1984. Gleason denied any involvement in criminal activity and claimed that the stockpile, while against the rules, was a convenience that avoided the trouble of turning in the ammunition. Gleason's court-martial conviction, for threatening to kill a superior officer, were what initially drew attention to the battalion's activities, the Examiner said. The newspaper did not say whether the Gleason case was related to the stockpiling claims.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Rights Groups Say They'll Appeal $4.2 Million Verdict
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights activists say they will appeal a verdict that awarded $4.2 million to a Las Vegas showman secretly filmed striking the pet orangutans used in his act. ``We are appalled,'' said Ingrid Newkirk, national director of the Washington, D.C.-based People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. ``I believe this ruling will be overturned.'' Entertainer Bobby Berosini said he planned a nationwide talk-show tour to ``expose the animal rights activists for what they are: self-serving.'' But an attorney for the animal rights group promised to appeal the award handed down late Saturday afternoon by a state jury after four days of deliberations. ``He'll never see a penny of that money,'' said Philip Hirschkop. The animal rights group was assessed $2 million in damages on counts of invasion of privacy and defamation. Jeanne Roush, an investigator for the group, and former Stardust employee Ottavio Gesmundo, each was assessed $1 million in damages. The jury found the defendants innocent of actual malice and declined to award punitive damages. Gesmundo videotaped scenes of Berosini striking his orangutans before they went on stage for performances at the Stardust Hotel in July 1989. The videotapes were circulated to animal rights groups including the Performing Animal Welfare Society of Galt, Calif. Representatives of those two groups took the tapes to local and national media, including ``Entertainment Tonight.'' The performing animal welfare group and its president, Pat Derby, also were each assessed $100,000 in damages for defamation and invasion of privacy. Berosini said he had to beat the primates with a stick because they were spooked by dancers in his performance show. He claimed the adverse publicity from the animal rights groups damaged his career. Animal rights activists had descended on Las Vegas, picketing in front of the Stardust and encouraging the public to pass up the show. ``I was used as a pawn to make money,'' Berosini said of attacks by the animal rights groups. ``They were using this as a means of fund raising.''

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-A-Glance
With AM-Iraq-Kuwait Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the major developments Sunday in the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait:

SADDAM'S STATEMENT: Saddam Hussein says he is ready to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis if Israel withdraws from the occupied territories and Syria pulls out its troops from Lebanon. He says ``many will be burned'' if war breaks out. The Iraqi president also demands the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Saudi Arabia and the end to U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq, which forced him to ask his people to be thrifty with meat and clothing. Israel rejects Saddam's proposal as ``cheap propaganda.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the United States ``categorically rejects'' the Iraqi proposal.

U.S. MILITARY: A U.S. airman dies in Saudi Arabia in a car accident. He is the first American killed in the desert kingdom since President Bush ordered the U.S. military deployment last week. Defense analysts say sending U.S. military forces to Saudi Arabia will cost an estimated $300 million to $440 million a month.

MILITARY MOVES: Ten thousand Egyptian and Moroccan troops are joining the 50,000 U.S. soldiers moving into Saudi Arabia. Syria, a neighbor of Iraq, has also pledged troops. Turkish Premier Yildirim Akbulut says he will ask Parliament for the power to declare a state of war and send armed forces into combat if the crisis worsens.

FOREIGNERS IN IRAQ AND KUWAIT: A British citizen is reportedly shot in Kuwait near the Saudi border, and scores of foreigners return to their homelands with stories of rapes and killings by Iraqi soldiers. Penelope Nabokov, the 10-year-old California girl who was detoured by the blitzkrieg on her way to visit her mother, fled to freedom Saturday and was on her way to meet her parents Sunday. An Iraqi spokesman quoted by Baghdad radio said the authorities have been instructed to ``facilitate the travel of the Arabs and foreign residents in Kuwait and other cities of southern Iraq.'' It was not clear whether the spokesman meant foreigners in Kuwait could leave the country.

SANCTIONS: U.S. and allied warships poise to meet Iraqi tankers coming from the Persian Gulf, Red Sea or Mediterranean Sea. Iraq is dependent on oil exports to buy food and supplies for its 17 million people. Secretary of State James Baker says he doesn't believe nations will ignore the economic sanctions against Iraq because ``the independence of the industrialized world is at stake.''

ANTI-U.S. DEMONSTRATIONS: About 10,000 Palestinians demonstrate in a refugee camp in southern Lebanon in support of Iraq. Some chant ``Death to America!'' A PLO official says 500 youths are volunteering to fight with Iraq against a possible American attack. Another pro-Iraqi demonstration is reported in Jordan. In Bangladesh, hundreds rally against the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Showers, Thunderstorms Across Central U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms struck across the nation's midsection Sunday, dumping heavy rain on Nebraska and Iowa, and temperatures dipped to record lows in four Florida cities. The storms scattered along and ahead of a stationary front curving through the central United States extended from the Texas Panhandle through Missouri and southern Iowa to Lake Erie. Showers and thunderstorms also fell over Arkansas, isolated storms dotted the Gulf Coast and the southern Atlantic Coast and numerous showers and thunderstorms dampened extreme southern Florida. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. The storms produced locally heavy morning rains in eastern Nebraska and southwestern Iowa. More than 5 inches of rain has fallen in Randolph and south of Red Oak in southwestern Iowa. Streets were flooded in Kearney and Lincoln, Neb., and the National Weather Service issued a flash flood advisory for part of southeast Nebraska. Heavier rainfall for the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included 2.3 inches in Lincoln, Neb., and 1.27 inches in Lancaster, Pa. The temperature was 66 degrees in Hollywood, Fla., breaking the low-temperature record for the date of 69 set in 1977. Other Florida cities were record lows were set or tied were Melbourne (68 degrees, 70 in 1989); Miami (73, tie 1963); and West Palm Beach (70, tie 1984). The nation's cold spot Sunday morning was International Falls, Minn., where the temperature dropped to a record 39 degrees, breaking the old record of 40 degrees set in 1951. Temperatures were in the relatively balmy 60s in Nome, Alaska, early Sunday, for a record-tying 24 straight days the high there has been 60 degrees or above.

DOC.HEAD: Season's Seventh Depression Washes Out
DOC.TEXT: The hurricane season's seventh tropical depression lost its center and degenerated into a tropical wave far off in the eastern Atlantic Sunday, a forecaster said. At 6 p.m. EDT, satellite pictures showed the remnants of the depression were centered near 8 degrees north latitude and 45 degrees west longitude, or about 1,100 miles east-southeast of Trinidad. The wave still had top sustained winds of 30 mph Sunday evening, but they were expected to decrease and no further updates were planned, said Hal Gerrish, a hurricane specialist at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to November 30.

DOC.HEAD: East German Leader Blames Wall For Deepening German Divisions
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's prime minister, preparing to mark the 29th anniversary the Berlin Wall's construction, said Sunday it has created German divisions that even unification will not easily bridge. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere made his remarks in a statement released by the official ADN news agency on the eve of the annniversary of the Wall _ once a notorious Cold War symbol but now a crumbling relic in an era of reduced East-West tensions. De Maiziere said ``the joy over the fall of the Wall should not allow forgetting the lasting consequences of the division'' of Germany. ``The wall strengthened the distinct developments in both German states,'' de Maiziere said. ``State unity of Germany will not immediately lift differences in peoples' thinking and acting.'' De Maiziere warned his countrymen that ``the rapid disappearance of the Wall should not lead to expectations that an economic upswing could occur just as quickly.'' On Aug. 13, 1961, East German military and paramilitary units suddenly began laying the foundations for what was to become the Berlin Wall _ a barrier of concrete, steel and barbed wire dividing East and West Berlin. Communist authorities said the wall was necessary to preserve East Germany from Western subversion and prevent a mass exodus of skilled and professional workers to the West. More than 2.5 million East Germans had fled to the West from 1949 until the Wall went up. The barrier _ watched over by armed guards with ``shoot to kill'' orders _ reduced that flow to a trickle. More than 200 East Germans were killed trying to escape to the West across the barrier that snaked through Berlin and along the border with West Germany. On Nov. 9, 1989, the reform Communists who ousted hard-liner Erich Honecker opened the Wall in a last-ditch effort to retain power. They had hoped to stem a flood of East Germans to West Germany that had reached more than 200,000. By the end of this year, East and West Germany plan to merge to form one country. East Germans enjoyed the most prosperous economy in the Soviet bloc, but now face a major challenge in trying to catch up with the West German economic powerhouse. The East German economy is reeling _ with growing unemployment and factory closings _ as it plunges into capitalism after 40 years of Communism. Richard Schroeder, the Social Democratic caucus leader in the East German Parliament, said ``the Wall concealed and postponed the economic ruin'' of East Germany, in a statement released by ADN. He said the enthusiasm that greeted the opening of the Wall in November has disappeared because East Germany has plunged into a ``deep crisis'' following its July 1 economic union with West Germany. The East German press, once forced to praise the country's Communist leaders for erecting the Wall, joined the new democratically elected leaders in criticizing the former barrier. The Berliner Zeitung said the Wall ``in the long run failed to bring about'' the economic improvement the former Communist leaders had promised after building it. Numerous ceremonies were planned for Monday in both East and West Berlin along the 100-mile strip where the Wall once divided the former German capital. Most of the Wall has been removed from the central part of the city, and the outer ring on the edge of the city is expected to be gone by 1991. On Monday night, the Rolling Stones will perform at an outdoor stadium in East Berlin. The Japanese symphony orchestra Saito Kinen, conducted by Seiji Ozawa, will also give what is being billed as ``The Berlin Wall Memorial Concert.''

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Carrying Iraqi Oil To Dock In New Jersey
LaserPhoto PX2
DOC.TEXT: A tanker loaded with nearly 1 million barrels of Iraqi oil arrived Sunday, but the shipment did not fall under President Bush's embargo on Iraqi oil, the Coast Guard said. ``It was all bought before the thing started,'' said Coast Guard Lt.j.g. Jonathan Burton. The shipment was the the first to arrive in the area since the embargo went into effect Aug. 2. The tanker Nautica arrived at Mobil Oil Corp.'s Paulsboro Refinery in this port across the Delaware River from Philadelphia. The Bahamian-registered tanker left Turkey on July 25, more than a week before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, said refinery spokeswoman Ida Walker. Bush imposed the embargo hours after the attack. Mobil requested instructions from the Treasury Department, which told the oil company to accept the oil and deposit the payment due Iraq into a frozen account, Ms. Walker said. She did not know how much the shipment cost or how much money Mobil was to deposit in the account. Mobil plans to process the crude into a lubricating oil commonly used in cars and ships, Ms. Walker said.

DOC.HEAD: San Francisco Examiner Editorial Calls for Legalizing Drugs
DOC.TEXT: The San Francisco Examiner, in one of the first pro-legalization editorials by a big-city newspaper, said Sunday that the sale and use of drugs should be made legal in the United States. An editorial called the federal war against drugs ``a colossal waste of effort, money and human resources.'' ``All anti-drug laws should be repealed,'' it said. ``The war on drugs should be called off. Just declare victory, play `76 Trombones' and march out. It always gets applause.'' The federal government last week finished a much-publicized sweep against marijuana plantations in Humboldt County, about 200 miles north of San Francisco, the first time army troops were used against drugs in the United States. The operation was termed a success by federal officials, the Examiner noted, although the 1,400 marijuana plants destroyed was ``not enough to put a dent in the supply of marijuana.'' ``Any way you slice it, there is no denying that this politician-declared war has been just about effective as the war on poverty, the war on crime and the war on cancer put together, which is to say, a complete defeat,'' the editorial said. ``The time has come to legalize the sale and use of drugs. Treat them all like alcohol, which is legal though its sale is subject to controls.''

DOC.HEAD: Smokey II Dies of Cancer
DOC.TEXT: America's most recent spokesbear for the prevention of forest fires died of liver cancer in his pen at the National Zoo, veterinarians determined Sunday. The 20-year-old black bear called Smokey II, also known as Little Smokey, began shaking late Saturday and could not keep his balance, prompting his keeper to summon veterinarians, said zoo spokesman Robert Hoage. Doctors injected steroids via a blowgun late Saturday, but Hoage said they had no effect on the bear's condition. Because he was wild, keepers and veterinarians could not get close enough to examine him. A necropsy, the animal equivalent of an autopsy, was performed at the zoo Sunday, revealing advanced liver cancer, the spokesman said. Hoage said his death could not be termed premature since black bears live only to their mid-twenties. The original Smokey the Bear was 26 when he died in 1976. The chocolate brown-colored Smokey II came to the National Zoo in Northwest D.C. from the Lincoln National Forest in New Mexico. He was the only breed of its kind to be housed by the zoo. Black bears are known to exist in one of four colors; black, dark brown, cinnamon light brown and silver grey. Little Smokey stood about 5-feet-6-inches tall and weighed about 200 to 250 pounds, Hoage said. He was given to the zoo in 1971 by the New Mexico Department of Game and Fish and was only 1{-years-old at the time. The original Smokey also came from the Lincoln National Forest, although their immediate families were not related. Smokey I was flown back to New Mexico after his death and Hoage said officials were not sure where Little Smokey would be laid to rest.

DOC.HEAD: Barge Buckles, Spilling At Least 20,000 Gallons into Ship Channel
DOC.TEXT: A barge being loaded with heavy fuel oil at an Arco Petrochemical dock buckled Sunday, spewing at least 20,000 gallons of oil into the Houston Ship Channel, Coast Guard officials said. ``It's unusual in the way that it happened,'' said Coast Guard Senior Chief Dale Eichmann. ``It was just sitting there at the dock and apparently, it just started buckling in half. The metal deck folded down on top of it and cracked it down the middle.'' No. 6 fuel oil spilled from two center tanks as a crease cut across the barge at the dock in southeast Houston. Cleanup crews from Arco and Lyondell Petrochemical Co. were able to string containment booms around the area after the 10 a.m. accident, Eichmann said, and a cleanup company later joined the effort. Lyondell is a former division of Atlantic Richfield Co. ``We got a primary boom out there pretty quick,'' Eichmann said. ``Then we set up two containment booms stretched across the turning basin and stuck some absorbent pads in the cracks (of the barge) and that shut down the discharge pretty well.'' The barge had been loaded with 630,000 gallons of oil, Eichmann said. It had a capacity of 840,000 gallons. David Harpole of the Lyondell salvage crew said another barge was located adjacent to the ruptured one, helping to cut down the spread of the oil. A third barge was brought to the area to transfer remaining oil from the ruptured vessel, he said. The Houston Ship Channel remains open, but Coast Guard officials warned ships in the area to slow down. The Coast Guard on Friday completed a two-week cleanup of a 700,000-gallon oil spill that occurred July 28 when a Greek tanker collided with two barges under tow in the Houston Ship Channel. Earlier this year, the Norweigan tanker Mega Borg spilled 3.9 million gallons of Angolan crude into the Gulf of Mexico off Galveston when an explosion ripped through the vessel, killing four crewmembers and injuring 17 others.

DOC.HEAD: Students Riot Over Proposed Caste Quota System for Government Jobs
DOC.TEXT: A government plan to set aside more government jobs for low caste Indians has sparked protests against reverse discrimination by other students. Sunday newspapers reported that police arrested scores of students and took up protective positions at key government buildings after four days of protests in the eastern state of Bihar. Students sabotaged train engines, burned wagons and disrupted rail traffic in Bihar, the nation's poorest state, the newspapers said. They also stoned cars, set fire to empty buses and a post office, and torched several government cars. In the capital, Delhi University was virtually emptied by a student boycott. On Friday, police used tear gas and bamboo clubs to break up a student demonstration near the government and Parliament complex. The trouble began when Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced in Parliament on Thursday that a further 27 percent of federal jobs would be reserved for people from ``socially and educationally backward classes.'' That would be in addition to an existing quota of 22 percent for low caste Hindus and tribes in public service and higher education jobs, according to a list drawn up after India became independent in 1947 and included in the Constitution. The quota has never been filled completely. If the government's plan is carried out, 49 percent of government jobs will be set aside for low castes, and 51 percent will be awarded purely on merit. Singh said he was endorsing a 10-year-old report by an official commission which recommended expanding the quota for government jobs for people from disadvantaged classes, defined by their income, social position and education. According to the Sunday Observer newspaper, the disadvantaged castes identified by the commission comprise 43.7 percent of the population, or about 385 million people. In India's highly structured society, hundreds of castes and subcastes have been delineated in a strict hierarchy by thousands of years of Hindu tradition. Modern India, an avowedly secular nation whose population is 82 percent Hindu, is pledged to discard the caste system and build an egalitarian state. But the caste system persists, particularly in rural areas, dictating rules of behavior, occupation and association. Singh said implementing the commission's report was ``a momentous decision for social justice.'' His announcement was greeted by congratulatory thumping on tables from all sides of the legislature. Critics in the Indian press accused Singh of engaging in a grandstand populist ploy aimed at boosting support for his party. Singh's 8-month-old coalition government has been wracked by infighting, leading some analysts to predict elections as early as next year.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Reiterates U.S. Resolve to Block Oil Shipments From Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 9-12, ``Baker was asked xxx to inlude additional from Baker and Scowcroft on food embargo; edits grafs 30-31 to delete first reference to Scowcroft, now higher
DOC.TEXT: The United States, citing the legal authority of United Nations sanctions, will stop oil shipments from leaving Iraq and block food and other supplies from entering the country, the government said Sunday. Asked during a golf outing in Maine whether the embargo would include food, President Bush replied: ``Just watch. Everything.'' Questioned later on whether a blockade would be considered an act of war, the president said, ``I consider interdiction of shipping to be in accord with the Chapter VII action taken by the United Nations. No point getting into all these semantics. ``The main thing,'' said Bush, ``is to stop the oil from coming out of there and that is what we're going to do.'' Earlier Sunday, both Secretary of State James A. Baker III and White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater had underscored the extent of the U.S. determination to squeeze Iraq economically. The United States will do ``whatever is necessary'' to enforce the sanctions, Fitzwater said in a written statement issued on behalf of the president. Although neither Fitzwater nor Baker would be specific about any U.S. action, the secretary of state said the U.S. response would begin ``almost immediately.'' Kuwait's government-in-exile asked the world community to enforce the U.N. sanctions and Baker said that gave the United States legal authority to halt any Iraqi oil exports. Baker was asked by reporters later whether the United States was considering blocking shipments of goods other than oil to Iraq. ``The request that's been received from the legitimate government of Kuwait is that we, we and the other countries, countries that support the U.N. resolution, do what we can to implement these U.N. sanctions,'' said Baker. ``Now those sanctions go beyond just oil.'' On the CBS television show ``Face the Nation,'' national security adviser Gen. Brent Scowcroft was asked about the prospect of sanctions eventually resulting in ``starving people in Kuwait.'' ``Well, we'll deal with that when we get to that point,'' said Scowcroft. ``The president has decided that the United States will do whatever is necessary to see that relevant UN sanctions are enforced,'' Fitzwater said from Kennebunkport, Me., where Bush is vacationing. ``The United States will coordinate its efforts with the governments of other nations to whom the Kuwaiti government has made similar requests.'' Baker characterized the contemplated action as an ``interdiction'' rather than a blockade, which in diplomatic parlance could be considered an act of war. Baker, who spoke on the ABC television program ``This Week With David Brinkley,'' said Iraq now has ``a significant presence'' in southern Kuwait consisting of about 120,000 troops in nine divisions. ``There's not much to prevent him, if he should decide to do so, from launching offensive operations from there,'' Baker said. But the commander of the U.S. military effort in Saudi Arabia said Sunday that U.S. forces could repel an attack, even though they are currently outnumbered on the ground. American air and naval power could neutralize any Iraqi attack, he said. ``We have built up a great deal of force over there now ... and if they do make an attack they are going to pay a price for it,'' Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf said at United States Central Command headquarters in Florida before leaving for Saudi Arabia.
