The United States, France and Britain have sent ships to the Persian Gulf region in an effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait and to defend strategic, oil-rich Saudi Arabia from possible Iraqi attack. The United States also has committed an estimated 50,000 ground troops to the operation. Egypt and Morocco also have sent troops to Saudi Arabia to counter Iraqi forces massed along the border in Kuwait. Baker would not comment specifically about what the United States intends to do if an Iraqi tanker now off the coast of Saudi Arabia moves to claim Iraqi oil shipped by pipeline across Saudi Arabia. In Baghdad, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein warned that ``many will be burned'' if war breaks out in the Middle East. He linked any possible Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait to an Israeli surrender of the Arab-claimed territories it occupies. Hussein also demanded the withdrawal of U.S. and other forces from Saudi Arabia and an end to international economic sanctions against his nation. Saddam said that if the international community wants foreign forces kept in the region, they should be replaced by Arab forces ``with the (U.N.) Security Council making all the arrangements'' on which nationalities should be involved. In Maine, Bush said: ``I didn't see anything ... pleasing in there (Saddam's statement) at all. None. Nothing.'' Asked whether he would welcome Iran's participation in the effort against Iraq, Bush said, ``Anybody to help enforce those sanctions, that's who we want.'' Fitzwater said the United States ``categorically rejects'' Saddam's demands and repeated U.S. and UN calls for the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Scowcroft said the United States does not intend to overthrow Saddam but rather to try to ``affect his behavior.'' He declined to comment on reported U.S. covert action against Saddam's government. On another subject, Baker said he hopes world pressure on Baghdad will soon force Iraq to release some 3,500 Americans detained in Kuwait and Iraq. Americans ``We hope they will be allowed to come out soon,'' he said. ``The truth of the matter is that (Iraq) has restricted the right of all foreign nationals to leave. ... This runs against all international behavior norms.'' Abdul Amir al-Anbari, the Iraqi ambassador to the United Nations, characterized the resolution adopted by last week's Arab summit in Cairo to condemn Iraq as having ``doubtful validity.'' He predicted that any Arab force sent to protect Saudi Arabia will be ``nominal.'' And President Turgut Ozal of Turkey said he is confident his nation will enjoy the support of the NATO alliance if a shooting war breaks out with its neighbor, Iraq. ``We have a strong army, we can defend ourselves,'' he said. Both the Iraqi president and the Turkish president commented while appearing on ABC television's Brinkley program. Meanwhile, the Pentagon released details of the first American killed in the desert kingdom since Bush ordered the U.S. military deployment last week. The Pentagon identified the dead man as Air Force Staff Sgt. John Campisi. The 30-year-old aircraft maintenance technician was from Covina, Calif., and was assigned to Offutt Air Force Base in Nebraska. Pentagon sources who spoke on condition of not being identified by name said a preliminary investigation indicated Campisi was hit by a truck on a darkened runway. The sources said Campisi may have been wearing protective ear covering, inhibiting his ability to hear the oncoming truck. Further details were not available.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Rejects Iraqi Conditions, Forms Ties With Syria
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 10-12, ``Later in the xxx to include additional Bush quotes, which also are in AM-US-Iraq Rdp
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Sunday firmly rejected conditions set by Saddam Hussein for ending the Persian Gulf crisis and put aside differences with Syria long enough to cement an alliance against Baghdad. The White House reacted swiftly to Saddam's demand that Israel surrender the occupied territories as a partial price for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. Saddam also demanded an end to U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq and the pullout of U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, referring to Saddam's conditions, said, ``the United States categorically rejects them.'' He said, ``These latest conditions and threats are another attempt at distracting from Iraq's isolation and at imposing a new status quo.'' Bush said he was determined that global economic sanctions against Iraq will choke off its oil exports. The White House cited a letter from the emir of Kuwait as the legal basis for U.S. efforts to insure that sanctions ``are immediately and effectively implemented.'' While avoiding use of the word ``blockade,'' Bush said the U.N.-approved embargo ``gave us broad authority, working in conjunction with others, to do whatever is necessary to see no oil goes out.'' In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the United States would intercept Iraqi oil shipments. ``Let's not use the word blockade,'' Baker said, adding that he preferred the word ``interdiction.'' Bush, during a golf outing, was asked by reporters whether the embargo would include food. He replied: ``Just watch. Everything.'' Asked if he was pleased that Saddam was talking about a negotiated settlement, even if the terms were unacceptable, Bush said crisply: ``I didn't see anything to be pleasing in there at all. None. Nothing.'' Later in the afternoon, Bush was asked whether he regarded a blockade as an act of war. ``I consider interdiction of shipping to be in accord with the Chapter VII action taken by the United Nations,'' he said. ``No point getting into all these semantics. The main thing is to stop the oil from coming out of there and that is what we're going to do.'' Asked whether he would welcome Iran's participation, ``Anybody to help enforce those sanctions, that's who we want.'' At his oceanside home, the vacationing Bush pressed ahead with his telephone diplomacy to isolate Saddam, whose troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and now threaten the oil fields of Saudi Arabia. Bush, an early riser, called Syrian President Hafez Assad at 6 a.m. Later, the president told reporters, ``I'm very pleased that we're looking at this in the same way.'' Likewise, he said Assad declared that he was ``pleased to be together on this.'' Since arriving here Friday, Bush also has called Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and the emirs of Bahrain and Qatar. The United States says Syria continues to support terrorism, and the two differ sharply over Israel, but in this instance find themselves solidly united against Iraq. Sensing an opportunity to topple its longtime foe, Syria went along with the Arab League vote to send troops to the Persian Gulf as part of an Arab force against Saddam. Bush has committed an estimated 50,000 troops to Saudi Arabia to face Iraqi forces massed along that country's border with Kuwait. Fitzwater, in a written statement, said, ``We join the rest of the UN Security Council in unanimously calling for the immediate, complete and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and the restoration of Kuwait's legitimate government.'' He said that Bush had received a letter from Sheikh Jaber Alahmad Al-Sabah, the emir of Kuwait who fled his country as it was invaded, asking the United States to enforce sanctions against Iraq and Kuwait. ``In view of the emir's request,'' Fitzwater said, ``the president has decided that the United States will do whatever is necessary to see that relevant UN sanctions are enforced.'' He said the United States would coordinate its efforts with other nations that have received similar requests from the emir. While tracking developments in the tense Persian Gulf, Bush found time to go boating in foggy Atlantic waters and to go jogging back and forth for 20 minutes on an undeveloped road off Ocean Avenue. After two days of solid rain, the weather was mostly sunny and warm. Bush planned an afternoon golf match. Accompanied by his wife, Barbara, and nine grandchildren, as well as his son Neil and other relatives, Bush worshipped at St. Ann's Episcopal Church. A well-wisher called out, ``Doing a good job, Mr. President.'' Bush turned as he walked to the church and gave a thumbs-up signal.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Await Word of Loved Ones Held in Iraq, Kuwait
With AM-Iraq-Foreigners, Bjt
LaserPhoto XCLA1
DOC.TEXT: A Milwaukee man made a videotaped plea to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to release his wife and daughter, as relatives of Americans stranded in Iraq and Kuwait awaited word of loved ones Sunday from the State Department. ``I didn't sleep again last night,'' said Marjorie Walterscheid of Jacksboro, Texas, whose husband, Rainard, was among a group of Americans being held in hotels in the Iraqi capital, Baghdad. Mrs. Walterscheid said she was worried because her husband, who works for Santa Fe Drilling Co., had not responded to a message she sent Saturday via the State Department. There are an estimated 400 Americans in Iraq and 3,000 in Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2, according to the State Department. Iraq is not permitting most foreigners to leave either country. Mrs. Walterscheid received word Saturday about her husband and the other Americans from Michael Saba of Champaign, Ill., a businessman who was at the hotel and got out of Iraq. ``They can come down and swim and they're eating in the finest restaurant at the hotel, but they can't leave,'' she said. Madhavarao Murikipudi, a Milwaukee foundry superintendent and native of India, made the videotaped plea in hopes of securing the release of his 40-year-old wife, Prabhavathi, and his 9-year-old daughter, Sylaja. ``All I said was, `Mr. President Saddam Hussein, my name is Madhavarao Murikipudi,''' said Murikipudi, 47. ``I said my wife and daughter were on their way to India when they were stranded in Kuwait. ``I had to try,'' he said. ``I hope it gets to him.'' Murikipudi's wife and daughter were bound for India to visit relatives when their British Airways flight made a scheduled stop in Kuwait as Iraqi soldiers were crossing the border. They were among 39 Americans taken off the plane. The State Department has said consular officials have visited the Murikipudis in Baghdad and they are well. A copy of the tape was delivered Frdiay to the State Department by Rep. Gerald Kleczka, D-Wis., and another was to be delivered to the Iraqi Embassy in Washington on Monday, Kleczka said in a statement. The congressman said the Iraqi ambassador had agreed to review the tape and pass the information along to officials in Iraq. Donnita Cole of Odessa, Texas, said she still didn't know the whereabouts of her husband, John Henry Cole, an OGE Drilling Co. employee last seen Aug. 3 in front of the couple's apartment in a Kuwaiti village. The U.S. Embassy said Cole, 50, was fine Monday, but didn't say where he was, Mrs. Cole said. ``We're just sitting here with absolutely no knowledge, building all these scenarios in our heads,'' she said. ``That's the hard part of waiting.'' That wasn't her only worry. Mrs. Cole has a son in the military whose unit has been placed on standby to go to Saudi Arabia. ``And he told me not to do anything to stop him from going,'' she said, declining to say where he was assigned. ``He says he wants to go because his father is there, and I don't want him to go _ because his father is there.'' In Clarksville, Tenn., members of the 101st Airborne Divison, some dressed in camouflage, attended a church service Sunday where they were urged to ``pray for our country like we've never prayed before.'' The 101st, based at Fort Campbell, Ky., just across the state line from Clarksville, had learned the day before that the entire division would be going to the Mideast. About 300 people turned out at the First Assembly of God church, where the Rev. Billy R. Jones urged them to pray for a quick end to the conflict begun by Saddam. ``I'm really praying for this man that God will just put him down without bloodshed,'' Jones said. ``I don't know what the outcome is going to be in the Middle East, but I know one thing. I know our God is in control.'' Many in the congregation wept. But in the Detroit suburb of Farmington Hills, Patricia Heath said she was encouraged by the news that Penelope Nabokov, 10, and 10 other Americans had been released Saturday. Heath's brother, Kevin Bazner, 36, was aboard the British Airways airliner seized in Kuwait, along with his wife Dawn, 6-month-old son David and daughter Elizabeth, 6. Penelope and the others were released Saturday, but the Bazners remained behind.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Washington
Accident Claims Life of California Serviceman in Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throuhout with interview with slain serviceman's parents; ADDS byline; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A career military man from California died Sunday in an accident during troop preparation in Saudi Arabia, becoming the first American casualty of the military reaction to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the Pentagon said. John Campisi, a U.S. Air Force staff sergeant, was hit by a truck on a darkened runway, according to the Pentagon. Campisi, 30, was an aircraft maintenance technician from Covina, Calif. He was assigned to Offutt Air Force Base in Nebraska and had been in the military since he was 18, his parents said. Campisi left a wife and four children, two girls and two boys, his parents said. ``The main thing is that he was a wonderful father,'' said Campisi's mother, Marge Campisi, her voice choked with emotion in a telephone interview. ``He was involved in everything with those kids _ scout leader, religious classes. He always made time for his family.'' Campisi's' father, Salvatore Campisi, described his son as having ``the patience of Job.'' ``It will be very hard on those children,'' the elder Campisi said. John Campisi grew up in West Covina, a Los Angeles County suburb in the San Gabriel Valley about 20 miles east of downtown. He attended St. Christopher's School, a Catholic elementary school, and Edgewood High School, a public school. The elder Campisi said his son's favorite sports then were baseball and wrestling. Campisi is also survived by a sister and three brothers. One of the brothers is a naval chief petty officer and another recently enlisted in the Navy, Campisi's mother said. ``One of them just got back last week or he would have gone too,'' she said. Pentagon sources said Campisi may have been wearing protective ear wear, impeding his ability to hear the oncoming vehicle.

DOC.HEAD: American Girl Reunited with Parents after Escape from Baghdad
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old American girl who escaped across the desert after being stranded by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait was reunited with her parents Sunday, and calmly recounted some scary moments in her ordeal. Penelope Nabokov, detained in hotels in Kuwait and then Baghdad, reached freedom in Jordan on Saturday, and finally rejoined her parents, Peter and Isabelle, in Paris on Sunday. At a Paris news conference, the girl _ a frequent solo flier on visits to her anthropologist parents _ calmly recounted the moment she knew she might be in danger: ``I realized I was trapped in a war zone when we were moved to the airport hotel ... from my window we could see all the troops going into the airport grounds and runways, and we could see lots of tanks and men with arms.'' Thousands of Americans and other foreigners were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the Aug. 2 invasion. But the plight of Penelope, from the Oakland, Calif., suburb of Albany, captured the most public attention. She was flying unaccompanied from France to India, where her mother was doing research. The British Airways flight had a stopover in Kuwait, where the passengers were taken into custody by Iraqi soldiers. She and some of the other passengers later were taken to Baghdad and held in a hotel with a number of Americans, amid speculation Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein intended to hold Americans hostage. The U.S. Embassy persuaded the Iraqis to release the girl to Embassy custody, but the others were kept in the hotel, and all foreigners were told they couldn't leave Iraq. But Penelope, with 10 other Americans in several cars, made a grueling 72-hour, 660-mile drive to Iraq's border with Jordan, crossing to freedom at the Jordanian border outpost of Ruweishid on Saturday. The scariest moments, she said in press conference remarks reported by NBC news, were caused by her fellow travelers' reactions. Asked when she was frightened most, she said matter-of-factly: ``On the third day, 'cause the (airline) hostesses were starting to freak out too, and they were getting scared, and so that got me even more scared. That's when I got hysterical and started crying.''

DOC.HEAD: Finance Minister Says Germany Can't Afford to Move Government
DOC.TEXT: Finance Minister Theo Waigel said Sunday that a united Germany cannot afford to move its seat of government from Bonn to Berlin. ``I need, at the moment, every mark for the people, for investments and not for showcase building,'' Waigel said on the West German television program ``Bonn Direct.'' He also estimated that a supplementary budget to keep East Germany afloat the rest of this year would probably need to be ``something over 10 billion marks (about $6 billion).'' West Germany has already budgeted nearly $16 billion for this year to cover East Germany's budget deficit. East Germany's economic situation grows more dire with each day as it struggles to shift from 40 years of Communism to a capitalist economy. The two Germanys merged their economies and the powerful West German mark became the official currency of both states on July 1. More than 270,000 East Germans are out of work as businesses and factories fall to the rigors of capitalism and competition with West German producers. Some experts have predicted up to 3 million of East Germany's 8 million workforce could ultimately lose their jobs. All-German elections are planned for Dec. 2, but there are increasing calls for East Germany to exercise a provision of the West German Constitution for an immediate merger. Proponents of that idea say it is the only hope to control East Germany's economic downward spiral. Waigel said it is necessary to differentiate between the capital and seat of government in a united Germany, according to a transcript of the program on the West German network ZDF. He said moving the government from the West German capital Bonn to Berlin, Germany's old capital, cannot be financed ``in the coming years.'' West Germany had not built so many government buildings in Bonn just to abandon them, he said. East and West German negotiators have agreed Berlin will be the capital of a united nation. But they left open the question of whether the government would be located there. Their agreement must still be ratified by both German parliaments. Waigel, leader of the conservative Christian Social Union, the Bavarian sister party of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats, called the capital fight ``completely superfluous.'' Klaus Rauen, Bonn's deputy city manager, estimates it would cost at least $31 billion to relocate government offices and employees to Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Registry of Lost Properties Drawing Entries, Criticisms
DOC.TEXT: A registry of private Cuban properties seized by the revolution of Fidel Castro is being compiled in Miami by exiles eager to return home and recoup their losses if Castro is toppled. Hundreds of exiles from as far away as Italy are signing on to list the farms, homes and businesses they lost to the communist revolution. Others are opposed to the idea of a registry, saying Castro's die-hard government is even less likely to implement reforms if he can cite the registry as proof exiles are bent on revenge and retribution. The Expropriated Cuban Properties Registry is a private venture by Metro-Dade Commissioner Barry Schreiber and the University of Miami's Research Institute for Cuban Studies. The project was begun last week. ``I think that a number of Cubans, once the system changes, will want to make demands on their property,'' said Miami professor Jaime Suchlicki, who is collaborating on the project. ``Once the regime changes, they're going to say, `I had a house there. I had a business there. Can I get something out of it.''' Registry entries must list the address of the property, say how it was acquired, how and when it was lost, and give its estimated value at the time. Applicants must include supporting documents, such as deeds or wills or affidavits by neighbors or friends who knew of the property. A listing costs $150, with $15 going to the university and the rest to Schreiber to cover clerical, printing costs and other expenses. The one-page application states that a listing provides no guarantee that the claim is valid. But Schreiber and Suchlicki say the registry will be useful, especially if Castro falls and Cuba opens up. ``The most likely scenario is some sort of settlement whereby the Cuban and U.S. government will sit down and work out a long-term repayment of these properties,'' said the professor. Tony Costa, a director of the Cuban American National Foundation, which has spoken against the retrieval of nationalized properties, said the registry will be used by the Castro government to disparage exiles. ``If the goal is to help Cubans, it is negative,'' Costa said. ``The exiles' interest is not to recover properties, but for the regime to fall.'' Alberto Muller, a former political prisoner in Cuba, agreed. ``It is not the moment to talk about properties,'' he said. ``It is the moment to talk about freedom, democracy, reconciliation. Not property.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Tap Dancers, Milk-Walker Go for Records
LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Seekers of immortality through the Guinness Book of World Records said they broke two records in Manhattan on Sunday. A man walked 44 miles with a pint of milk on his head and 5,271 tap-dancers performed a choreographed routine. ``It was really quite loud,'' said Barbra Lewinski, a spokeswoman for Macy's, which sponsored the 12th annual mass tap dance. This year's event was a tribute to entertainer Sammy Davis Jr., who died in May. The tap dancers from across the country filled a city block outside Macy's department store on 34th Street at noon. The dancers said they beat the record set by some 4,877 enthusiasts last August outside the store, as recorded by Guinness. The Guinness organization, which certifies new records, could not be reached for comment Sunday; there was no answer at their New York office. On Manhattan's Lower East Side, another record was challenged as Ashrita Furman tried to regain the Guinness record for walking with a full pint of milk balanced on his head. The 35-year-old manager of a health food store from the borough of Queens walked around a track at a city park, and said he broke the record by doing 43} miles. Furman said he beat the record of 40.4 miles set a few months ago by an Indian, whose name he did not remember. That record had not yet made the Guinness Book. Furman's previous record for balancing a full milk bottle was 32.9 miles on Jan. 17, 1989. He also holds Guinness records for yodeling, somersaulting and pogo-stick jumping _ in 8 feet of water in the Amazon River in Peru, and on Mount Fuji in Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Breakdown Could Leave Caracas Without Water for Two Weeks
DOC.TEXT: The capital's main waterworks suffered an electrical breakdown Sunday, threatening to leave most of the city's 4 million people without water for two weeks, the government said. The accident caused an estimated $1 million in damage at the main water station serving Caracas, officials said. It was described as a ``short circuit'' at the plant on the Mariposa Reservoir 30 miles south of Caracas. No details were released, and there were no reports of injuries. About three quarters of Caracas will be without water while authorities search for parts and arrange for repairs, said city water official Victor Medina said. Many residents of Caracas have already spent two days without water because of unrelated repairs on a major pipeline in the city. Officials said they would keep hospitals, firefighters and other crucial services functioning by rerouting water from other suburban pipelines. A few neighborhoods will receive severely rationed water through the same system. Trucking companies are expected to supply water to large companies and apartment buildings, but residents of small buildings and private homes will have a tougher time getting water. Government spokesman Luis Vezga Godoy called on residents for their ``understanding and solidarity.'' He asked businesses, families and friends to rely on each other for help. ``We've never had an accident of this magnitude,'' he said. He added that the government was working as quickly as possible to restore water.

DOC.HEAD: Fires Spread, Over 200,000 Acres Burned in California's Dry Timberland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `About 2,800..' to UPDATE with soldiers entering firefight in Oregon; SUBS 12th graf, `The Finley ..' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with visit to burned town; picks up 13th graf, `Yosemite firefighters...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos XYOS1
DOC.TEXT: Lightning fires have burned more than 200,000 acres of California forest in the past week, and experts said Sunday it could get get ``much, much worse'' because of the lengthy drought. In Yosemite National Park, off limits to tourists since Friday, two fires had burned more than 15,000 acres. Flames were within two miles of the Merced Grove, a stand of giant sequoias, and within two miles of the Badger Pass ski area. Across the state, 14 fires were listed as major. Fires also burned Sunday in parts of Alaska, Idaho, Oregon, Utah and Washington state, said the Boise Interagency Fire Center in Idaho; a fire in south-central Montana was controlled late Saturday. The national firefighting command center said nearly 20,000 firefighters were at work on fires that had covered 856,000 acres, more than half of that acreage in Alaska. About 2,800 Army soldiers have begun firefighting training at bases in Washington state and Colorado. About 100 soldiers left Fort Lewis, Wash., on Sunday to relieve fatigued firefighters in Oregon. About 1,100 more were to follow Monday, said Maj. John Lundberg, a base spokesman. California's worst fire was in Tehama County about 200 miles north of Yosemite, where two fires not far apart had burned a total of 124,000 acres. In the Sequoia National Forest, southeast of Yosemite and northeast of Bakersfield, a fire had burned over 24,000 acres and firefighters worked to protect the communities of Kernville and Alta Sierra. ``The 200,000-acre figure for the state is probably pretty conservative,'' said Karen Terrill of the California Department of Forestry. ``What I hear the experts saying is that this could get to be much, much worse.'' The largest Tehama County fire, called the Campbell Complex, covered 112,000 acres. ``It's probably going to become twice that,'' Chris Parker of the CDF said. ``What we're seeing is the culmination of four years' drought.'' The Campbell fire was considered only 40 percent contained. The Finley Lake fire six miles away was burning uncontrolled over 12,000 acres and was expected to join the bigger one, Terrill said. State Highway 36 in the fire area, east of Red Bluff, was closed Sunday. ``The Campbell is the most difficult to fight, is eating up the most acreage, and is in an area that hasn't burned for about 50 years,'' she added. ``The Finley Lake fire is incredibly smoky.'' The Finley Lake fire by Sunday had destroyed 13 trailer homes, two houses and 27 outbuildings. A total of 127 structures have been consumed by fires since Aug. 3 across the state, including 66 of the 84 houses in the town of Foresta, at Yosemite. People allowed back into Foresta on Sunday saw the black trunks of trees rising out of smoldering white ash. A firefighter surveying the ruins drove a stake three feet into the earth, then pulled it out. The end was burned from ground temperatures of 300 degrees. ``To save this town, it would have taken a massive sprinker system,'' said Len McKenzie, chief naturalist at Yosemite. Yosemite firefighters took special precautions to protect the sequoia trees, some of them 2,000 years old, in Merced Grove. This included cleaning up forest debris in the area and treating the trees with a fire retardant. But the thick-barked sequoias have lived through other fires, Terrill noted, and probably could make it easily through another. Elsewhere in Yosemite, ``there's a degree of peacefulness, if you are not caught up in the frantic business of firefighting,'' said Jeff Nicholas, 39, curator of Yosemite's Ansel Adams photo gallery. ``This is the way it should be, quite and peaceful, without the sound of tour buses,'' he said. The park normally has up to 25,000 tourists visiting on summer weekends. The Yosemite fires were about 10 miles west of Yosemite Valley, the heavily visited site of Half Dome, El Capitan and Bridalveil Falls. In 1987, summer fires in California burned more than 750,000 acres. ``Last week, we were saying this would be nothing like 1987. There was very little humidity then,'' Terrill said Sunday. ``But it also wasn't the fourth year of drought in the state then.'' Lightning strikes _ almost 24,000 were counted by detection equipment from Aug. 3 through the weekend _ were believed to have caused all of the California fires. Elsewhere, firefighters appeared to be winning the battle Sunday against five major groups of lightning-caused fires that have burned across 119,420 acres of remote eastern Oregon forest and range land. The town of Burns, Ore., was about four miles from the Pine Springs Basin Complex of fires that had burned 73,700 acres. The blaze was 75 percent contained Sunday morning and full containment was expected by Monday evening. Firefighters took advantage of a break in the hot, dry weather and contained Idaho's larger range fires, including the 65,000-acre Thorn Creek blaze that damaged several outbuildings.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Paynesville
Doe Says He Wants to Stay in Office Another Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with spokesman saying Doe wants to stay in power; Western reporters detained and beaten; CORRECTS spelling of task force commander's name; EDITS to trim; DROPS byline; PRECEDES; no pickup
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The following is based in part on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith is among them.

President Samuel Doe wants to remain in office for at least a year after regional peacekeepers intervene to halt the civil war, a spokesman said Sunday. Doe's announcement reversed an earlier promise to resign by October. At least 18 civilians were killed when government soldiers attacked rebels trying to take an airport. Also Sunday, three Western news agency reporters were detained and beaten by government soldiers who threatened to shoot them as spies after they crossed through rebel lines. Among the reporters was Michael Goldsmith, 68, of The Associated Press. The reporters were brought under guard to Doe's heavily fortified mansion, where they were released and met with the government spokesman. Doe's move reverses an earlier offer he made in May to resign before elections scheduled for October in order to end the fighting, which has degenerated into tribal warfare and left 5,000 dead, mostly civilians. The rebels, who have accused Doe of corruption and human rights abuses during his 10 years in power, have demanded that he step down immediately. ``The best thing is for Doe to stay,'' his spokesman Selley Thompson told the reporters Sunday. ``If he decided to leave tomorrow there would be a bloodbath. The soldiers would go on a rampage. It's likely that, if Doe decided to leave, the government's soldiers might even take power.'' Thompson said Doe's earlier offer to step down was no longer valid, and he wanted to keep power for at least a year after the West African force intervened. In Freetown, Sierra Leone, the West African task force was assembling. It was expected to arrive in Monrovia later this week. Three ships carrying 1,000 Ghanaian soldiers arrived Sunday in Freetown after the leader of the five-nation West African peacekeeping force launched an urgent appeal for a cease-fire in the 8-month-old civil war. At least 400 Nigerian troops have arrived by air in Freetown. In Monrovia, rebel leader Prince Johnson told a pool of foreign journalists Saturday that he was sending a delegation to Freetown to make arrangements for the peacekeeping force to land in Monrovia's port, which he has controlled for the past two weeks. In the fighting, government troops mounted a successful counterattack Sunday, dashing rebel hopes of seizing the capital before the arrival of the West African force. Troops from the government's 72nd Battalion advanced behind an armored car Sunday morning from their camp in the Paynesville suburb on the city's eastern outskirts and cut off a group of rebels trying to take Spriggs Payne airfield. The rebel troops ran away as government troops advanced. The government forces opened fire on fleeing civilians. ``They killed my papa!'' cried a girl as she fled the fighting. One middle-aged man, relieved to be alive, kept gasping, ``Thank you Jesus, Thank you Jesus.'' Journalists counted the bodies of 15 civilians, including those of small children, lying in a half-filled culvert where they had tried to seek cover. Three other bodies lay in the road nearby. The rebel troops from Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front had bypassed the 72nd Battalion in its haste to lay siege to the capital. There were no figures for the number of government or rebel fighters involved, or for casualties among the combatants. Taylor and Johnson are rivals, and their forces have clashed in the past. The three Western reporters were detained by government troops after they had crossed on foot through Johnson's lines into government-controlled territory in the center of Monrovia. The reporters were accused of being spies. Soldiers seized watches, wallets and other valuables from the reporters. Some of the items were later returned by senior officers, but others vanished. Soldiers ripped the shirts off the reporters and forced them to walk shoeless to the presidential mansion. On the way, they were slapped, punched and threatened with rifle butts. Thompson and senior officers later apologized for the troops' behavior. ``You have to understand they're very nervous,'' said Lt. Col. Moses Thomas before the reporters were escorted to the Barclay Training Center. They later made their way back across rebel lines without incident. In his other remarks, Thompson again accused the U.S. military of intervening in the conflict. He said a U.S. helicopter sprayed tear gas on government troops in the city center early Sunday. The United States has consistently denied any involvement in the fighting. A four-ship U.S. naval squadron with Marines and helicopters has been stationed off the coast to help evacuate Americans and other foreigners. Earlier, the Liberian government claimed that Doe's mansion had been attacked by a U.S. helicopter and fired upon by a U.S. submarine. West African leaders decided at a summit last week in Banjul, Gambia, to send the peacekeeping troops to Liberia. Doe and Johnson have welcomed the initiative to end the civil war. The West African force will include troops from Ghana, Gambia, Guinea, Nigeria and Sierra Leone. Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo of Ghana is commander in chief of the West African force.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Rapist Captured in Manhunt
DOC.TEXT: A four-day manhunt for a parolee accused of murdering one woman and raping three others at an isolated campground ended with his capture Sunday. Roy Eugene Perkins, 30, was arrested in the woods just south of Berry, about 60 miles west of Birmingham, said Robert Flippo, an aide to Fayette County Sheriff James Lenard. About 50 law officers and volunteers took part in the search. Officers were conducting a final search of a patch of woods when they found Perkins. ``One of the officers walked up on him and he said, `Don't shoot,''' said Ronnie Finch, a reserve deputy. Perkins had suffered a bullet wound to the leg that required treatment at a hospital, but officials said it wasn't serious. He may have been shot in a struggle with one of his alleged victims last week, said Finch. Six of Perkins' relatives were arrested Saturday night and charged with hindering prosecution, said Fayette County police Sgt. Butch Hudson. ``They had been giving him food and helping him and we decided the next time we had any trouble out of them we were going to arrest them,'' Lenard said. The focus of much of the search was a cinder block house tucked in a campground in the deep woods. Perkins grew up in the woods, officers said, and all three rape victims were taken to the camphouse. In 1983 Perkins was convicted of second-degree rape and served seven years of a 10-year sentence at the West Jefferson Correctional facility before being paroled in May. Perkins allegedly raped a teen-age relative in July, assaulted a 23-year-old relative from Tuscaloosa last week, abducted and killed a woman on Thursday and raped a 31-year-old Fayette County woman.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle's South American Trip a Risky Venture
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Parked side by side, the twin motorcades filled the narrow street in Bogota, Colombia, idling in opposite directions, each with a black, flag-decked limousine flown in from Washington for the day. At a radioed signal, one rolled out, turned sharp left, paused while Vice President Dan Quayle stepped into the limousine, then sped from the city to the expressway on a tightly guarded trip to Catam Military Airport. Anyone bent on harming the vice president, in a city where drug terrorism still is a menace, would have had to pick between motorcades, and guess at a route out of town. Security was intensive at every stop on Quayle's three-day mission to Latin America last week. There were reinforced Secret Service guards, SWAT teams, cordons of police and military men in each nation. Rooftops were guarded, routes swept in advance. Even so, the trip was a bodyguard's nightmare, and some Quayle aides had argued against it. But agents who surveyed the sites said they could keep the vice president safe, and they did. The government will not discuss security arrangements for the officials it guards, and that includes costs. Security doesn't come cheap, especially in a foreign capital where violence is not uncommon. Traveling vice presidents are not usually provided with backup Air Force jetliners for emergency use when they travel. One was sent to Bogota for the Quayle visit, in case of trouble with Air Force Two. And while he was in Bogota for the inauguration on Tuesday, at least four Latin American officials who had come for the ceremony told him it was safer there than in Lima, Peru, his next stop. They told him they wouldn't go to the Peruvian capital just then. Fleets of five Army helicopters were sent to each city to lift Quayle and his traveling party to and from the airports. In Bogota, the weather closed in while the vice president was at the inauguration of Colombia's President Cesar Gaviria, so he drove out of town. In Lima, helicopters flew Quayle into the city Tuesday night, landing on the floodlit soccer field of the National Stadium. Security men prefer it because air routes can be varied, and motorcades are more vulnerable to attack. Hours before Quayle arrived there had been bomb-punctuated street demonstrations over soaring prices and an austerity program the new Peruvian government was instituting to try to rebuild a collapsing economy. The city was in a state of emergency. Visitors were advised against venturing from their hotels, lest they be caught up in random violence. Early the next morning, an explosion and gunfire could be heard from the U.S. ambassador's residence where Quayle spent the night. None of it altered Quayle's schedule, and he didn't see so much as a demonstrator. Despite the objections of his security staff, he insisted on visiting San Pablo Presbyterian Church, in a slum neighborhood 20 minutes from downtown, to tour a center for orphans of guerrilla violence in the Peruvian mountains. It is operated with support from the Quayles' church in McLean, Va., and he was determined to go there. Sharpshooters patrolled slum rooftops, scanning the maze of buildings and shacks as he came and went. Again, no problems. As Quayle flew home from Bolivia, with a stop in Haiti, where random violence also is ordinary, he said there had been warnings in advance that he would not be well received in the Andean capitals. He said he'd been told that there might be anti-American demonstrations and security trouble. ``That just didn't happen,'' Quayle said. He said it reflects new attitudes and improving relationships between the United States and Latin American nations. Had he worried about his safety? ``I didn't that much, but my wife did, and some others,'' he said. His trip to the capital cities contrasted with the brief, heavily guarded Bush visit to Cartagena, Colombia, Feb. 15 for the drug summit with the presidents of the same three nations. That meeting was held at a Colombian naval base, with 5,000 troops standing guard, warships offshore and helicopters patrolling overhead. Even so, Bush faced advance criticism for going. He said he wasn't ``going to do something stupid or macho,'' but was going to show support for the Colombian government in its drive against the cocaine cartels. Quayle's trip to Bogota, where no such iron security was possible, renewed that support for a successor government pledged to continue the anti-drug effort. The visits to Lima and La Paz were companion pieces in the followup to Cartagena. He was the highest ranking U.S. official to visit Lima since Richard M. Nixon went there as vice president in 1958, and was jeered and pelted with tomatoes and spoiled fruit. Nixon, like Quayle, had gone on to La Paz; no vice president had been there since. None had visited Haiti, Quayle's last stop, since Nixon in 1954. The vice president did not go bearing gifts; he carried no new messages, no new aid commitments. He came home satisfied that by going, he had demonstrated U.S. support for governments that are trying to cope with drugs and with economic woes. The fact that he went at some risk served to underscore his point.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Uncertainty Makes Fed Choices More Difficult
Also moved in advance
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's invasion of Kuwait forced economists to reevaluate their projections, but left many even more convinced that the U.S. economy is weakening while also facing the possibility of higher inflation. Developments in the weeks preceding the Iraqi invasion already had economists warning of higher inflation and weaker economic growth. ``In a sense, the oil price increase only reinforces what was happening before,'' said Alan Levenson, an economist at the Wefa Group, a Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. economic forecasting firm. ``We've been through oil shocks before, now we have to make some judgments about where the dust will settle this time,'' he said. One key to the economy's direction is how the Federal Reserve will act. As a matter of policy the Fed doesn't disclose its intentions, but it has enormous power to influence economic growth through two principal means: controlling the supply of money in the banking system and adjusting rates banks pay to borrow. The spotlight on what the central bank's strategy might be has brightened because of events in the Middle East. Before the Iraqi invasion there were signs of economic weakness, which suggested the Fed would move to ease credit. July's unemployment figures showed the jobless rate reaching a 2-year high; July's Purchasing Managers Index slipped below 50, indicating that the manufacturing sector might be in decline, and the Fed's own regional survey showed economic growth was slowing. Wholesale prices in July edged down 0.1 percent, the government said Friday. But analysts said the figures may indicate the last respite from inflation before the effects of soaring oil costs linked to the Mideast crisis are felt. The Fed is faced with the same choices it had before the oil price increase. How much should it ease the money supply to offset economic weakness, but avoid increasing the potential for inflation? The weakening economy and higher inflation put the Fed in a common, but no less troublesome, predicament on how to deal with interest rates. Increasing the supply of money in the economy would lower interest rates and spur more spending, possibly giving the economy a dose of vitality. However with more money floating around, inflation could accelerate. Prices may already be pulled upward across the economy by the increase in oil. Holding back on the money supply, however, could spur higher interest rates and make it more difficult to buy new cars and homes and build new factories. Irwin Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co., said fears of inflation are exaggerated. Higher gasoline prices won't remain after the summer peak driving season ends Labor Day, he said. With less consumer demand, it will be even more difficult for oil companies to pass along higher wholesale costs, he said. ``It's been our assertion for some time now that the U.S. economy entered into a recession in the second quarter,'' Kellner said. Assuming the Middle East situation settles down, Kellner said he expects the Fed to loosen the money supply after its policymaking Federal Open Market Committee meets Aug. 21. ``If it hadn't been for the invasion we would have seen easing already,'' Kellner said. ``The big question is will it stick or not. No we're not going to return to $20 a barrel anytime soon, but will there be some decreases?'' Ray Stone, of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc., said. ``The higher oil prices makes it harder for the Fed to ease'' the money supply now, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Chief Determined To See Company Survive
DOC.TEXT: Fred Currey's dream Greyhound Lines Inc. is getting a little frayed around the edges, what with a strike by bus drivers and others' doubts about his company paying its bills. But the man who led the 1987 leveraged buyout of the bus company remains determined. ``You're damned right I believe in the system and you're damned right I see it rebuilt,'' Currey said during an interview in his starkly modern office in a Dallas skyscraper. ``I intend to finish exactly what the hell I started.'' Others aren't so sure. ``We think the company is on the brink of extinction here,'' said Earle Putnam, general counsel of the Amalgamated Transit Union, the umbrella organization over Greyhound drivers' union. Some analysts privately wonder if Greyhound this summer is building up the cash reserves it needs to survive the winter's slack travel. Greyhound's 6,300 drivers went on strike March 2 after negotiations broke down over a new contract to replace the one Currey had negotiated in 1987. Three months into the strike, Greyhound filed for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors, blaming increased legal and security costs required to combat the initially violent walkout. The bankruptcy remains in its early stages, with current management still running the company. No reorganization plan is due until October, and since extensions on initial plan deadlines are frequently granted, Greyhound spokesman George Gravley says the company's plan should be ready by early November. Currey promises a ``high-quality'' plan, ``reorganized around a viable market.'' The reorganized Greyhound is likely to resemble the old Greyhound, streamlined somewhat. ``Our strategy at operating this business turned around a dying business,'' he said, so a reorganization plan will ``employ exactly the same strategies, updated and enhanced, that we employed'' before the bankruptcy. Currey, a career bus executive, led a team of investors in 1987 that paid $270 million for the bus operations of Greyhound Corp., since renamed Greyhound Dial Corp. A few months later, the investors plunked down another $80 million for Dallas-based Trailways Lines Inc., the largest Trailways franchisee. After merging the two operations, Currey ran the nation's only intercity bus company. Ridership had been falling each year before the buyout, bottoming out at 6.09 billion passenger miles in 1986. After the buyout, ridership increased each year, hitting 7.48 billion passenger miles in 1989. Greyhound also turned its first profit that year, earning $730,000 on about $1 billion in revenues after losing about $20 million over the previous two years. Although the company has continued to operate using replacement drivers, the strike slashed ridership and the meager profits. Ridership slowly as returned to levels fluctuating between 70 percent and 80 percent of last year. ``We're now through the '87 level,'' Currey said, predicting ``it won't take three years'' to recover to profitable levels. Revenues are covering operating costs, he said. But in the transportation industry, travel delayed is travel lost, and the summer is the busiest time of the year. ``The objective indicators are that this company has a very severe financial problem just operating,'' said the union's Putnam. Although he won't provide figures until the reorganization plan is ready, Currey says Greyhound is building sufficient cash flow to attract new capital. ``We are building cash balances,'' Gravley said. ``We're having a good summer. Things are going pretty well. Business as usual has been our theme song.''

DOC.HEAD: Western Union Replaces Union Employees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: EDITS throughout, UPDATES with details on workers represented by CWA, wages. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Western Union Corp. on Saturday locked out 2,000 employees in the middle of contract talks with their union. The company did not indicate whether the workers would be rehired if it signs a new contract with their union, the Communications Workers of America, which represents a total of 2,500 workers at Western Union. Western Union said the replacements would not affect its money-transfer, telex, electronic mail and paper-based message services. ``We sincerely regret that, in the absence of a union contract, we have reluctantly had to take this defensive action,'' said Robert J. Amman, Western Union president and chief executive officer. ``We cannot operate under the ever-present threat of an employee strike while continuing to bear the cost required to ensure that the company would survive one.'' Western Union has a total of 16,000 employees. About half the employees represented by CWA are recording operators, and the others are mostly customer relations clerks, clerical workers and field technicians. Dan Beckstead, the chief union negotiator, deplored the lockout, saying the union had not given the company any indication it intends to strike. ``In fact, we told them we wanted to continue to negotiate in an attempt to reach an agreement,'' Beckstead said. CWA workers have authorized their leadership to call a strike. Western Union said many of the replaced CWA workers were from its central telephone bureaus in Bridgeton, Miss., and Reno, Nev.; its computer centers in Middletown, Va., and Bridgeton. It temporarily replaced them with workers from Western Union headquarters and trained temporary replacements, the company said. The company has been negotiating with representatives of the CWA since July 23. The previous two-year contract expired Aug. 6, but management and union negotiators have continued to meet to try to agree on a new pact. Management on Aug. 8 proposed a 90-day extension of the old contract, but the offer was rejected by the CWA. The contract issues include wages, health care and job classifications, as well as Western Union's right to use outside contractors and hire part-time workers. The operators average about $10 an hour. Beckstead said Western Union has not responded to the union's latest offer made Friday. The company, however, said the union had until midnight Sunday to agree to a 90-day contract extension.
